questions.text: What is the purpose of the preselector in a communications receiver?
distractors: To provide a range of AGC time constants
To allow selection of the optimum RF amplifier device
questions.answer: To increase rejection of unwanted signals

questions.label: E4D10
questions.text: What does a third-order intercept level of 40 dBm mean with respect to receiver performance?
distractors: Signals less than 40 dBm will not generate audible third-order intermodulation products
The receiver can tolerate signals up to 40 dB above the noise floor without producing third-order intermodulation products
A pair of 1 mW input signals will produce a third-order intermodulation product which is 40 dB stronger than the input signal
questions.answer: A pair of 40 dBm signals will theoretically generate a third-order intermodulation product with the same level as the input signals

questions.label: E4D11
questions.text: Why are third-order intermodulation products created within a receiver of particular interest compared to other products?
distractors: The third-order intercept is much higher than other orders
Third-order products are an indication of poor image rejection
Third-order intermodulation produces three products for every input signal within the band of interest
questions.answer: The third-order product of two signals which are in the band of interest is also likely to be within the band

questions.label: E4D12
questions.text: What is the term for the reduction in receiver sensitivity caused by a strong signal near the received frequency?
questions.answer: Desensitization

questions.label: E4D13
questions.text: Which of the following can cause receiver desensitization?
questions.answer: Strong adjacent channel signals

questions.label: E4D14
questions.text: Which of the following is a way to reduce the likelihood of receiver desensitization?
distractors: Increase the receiver front end gain
Switch from fast AGC to slow AGC
questions.answer: Decrease the RF bandwidth of the receiver

subTopics.label: E4E
subTopics.description: Noise suppression: system noise; electrical appliance noise; line noise; locating noise sources; DSP noise reduction; noise blankers; grounding for signals

questions.label: E4E01
questions.text: Which of the following types of receiver noise can often be reduced by use of a receiver noise blanker?
distractors: All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Ignition noise

questions.label: E4E02
questions.text: Which of the following types of receiver noise can often be reduced with a DSP noise filter?
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E4E03
questions.text: Which of the following signals might a receiver noise blanker be able to remove from desired signals?
distractors: Signals which are constant at all IF levels
Signals which appear at one IF but not another
Signals which have a sharply peaked frequency distribution
questions.answer: Signals which appear across a wide bandwidth

questions.label: E4E04
questions.text: How can conducted and radiated noise caused by an automobile alternator be suppressed?
distractors: By installing filter capacitors in series with the DC power lead and a blocking capacitor in the field lead
By installing a noise suppression resistor and a blocking capacitor in both leads
By installing a high-pass filter in series with the radio's power lead and a low-pass filter in parallel with the field lead
questions.answer: By connecting the radio's power leads directly to the battery and by installing coaxial capacitors in line with the alternator leads

questions.label: E4E05
questions.text: How can noise from an electric motor be suppressed?
distractors: By installing a high pass filter in series with the motor’s power leads
By installing a bypass capacitor in series with the motor leads
By using a ground-fault current interrupter in the circuit used to power the motor
questions.answer: By installing a brute-force AC-line filter in series with the motor leads

questions.label: E4E06
questions.text: What is a major cause of atmospheric static?
questions.answer: Thunderstorms

questions.label: E4E07
questions.text: How can you determine if line noise interference is being generated within your home?
distractors: By checking the power line voltage with a time domain reflectometer
By observing the AC power line waveform with an oscilloscope
By observing the AC power line voltage with a spectrum analyzer
questions.answer: By turning off the AC power line main circuit breaker and listening on a battery operated radio

questions.label: E4E08
questions.text: What type of signal is picked up by electrical wiring near a radio antenna?
distractors: A differential-mode signal at the AC power line frequency
Harmonics of the AC power line frequency
questions.answer: A common-mode signal at the frequency of the radio transmitter

questions.label: E4E09
questions.text: What undesirable effect can occur when using an IF noise blanker?
distractors: Received audio in the speech range might have an echo effect
The audio frequency bandwidth of the received signal might be compressed
FM signals can no longer be demodulated
questions.answer: Nearby signals may appear to be excessively wide even if they meet emission standards

questions.label: E4E10
questions.text: What is a common characteristic of interference caused by a touch controlled electrical device?
distractors: The interfering signal sounds like AC hum on an AM receiver or a carrier modulated by 60 Hz hum on a SSB or CW receiver
The interfering signal may drift slowly across the HF spectrum
The interfering signal can be several kHz in width and usually repeats at regular intervals across a HF band
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E4E11
questions.text: Which is the most likely cause if you are hearing combinations of local AM broadcast signals within one or more of the MF or HF ham bands?
distractors: The broadcast station is transmitting an over-modulated signal
You are receiving sky wave signals from a distant station
Your station receiver IF amplifier stage is defective
questions.answer: Nearby corroded metal joints are mixing and re-radiating the broadcast signals

questions.label: E4E12
questions.text: What is one disadvantage of using some types of automatic DSP notch-filters when attempting to copy CW signals?
distractors: Any nearby signal passing through the DSP system will overwhelm the desired signal
Received CW signals will appear to be modulated at the DSP clock frequency
Ringing in the DSP filter will completely remove the spaces between the CW characters
questions.answer: A DSP filter can remove the desired signal at the same time as it removes interfering signals

questions.label: E4E13
questions.text: What might be the cause of a loud roaring or buzzing AC line interference that comes and goes at intervals?
distractors: Arcing contacts in a thermostatically controlled device
A defective doorbell or doorbell transformer inside a nearby residence
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E4E14
questions.text: What is one type of electrical interference that might be caused by the operation of a nearby personal computer?
distractors: A loud AC hum in the audio output of your station receiver
A clicking noise at intervals of a few seconds
A whining type noise that continually pulses off and on
questions.answer: The appearance of unstable modulated or unmodulated signals at specific frequencies

questions.label: E4E15
questions.text: Which of the following can cause shielded cables to radiate or receive interference?
distractors: Low inductance ground connections at both ends of the shield
Tying all ground connections to a common point resulting in differential mode currents in the shield
questions.answer: Common mode currents on the shield and conductors

questions.label: E4E16
questions.text: What current flows equally on all conductors of an unshielded multi-conductor cable?
questions.answer: Common-mode current

subTopics.label: E5A
subTopics.description: Resonance and Q: characteristics of resonant circuits: series and parallel resonance; definitions and effects of Q; half-power bandwidth; phase relationships in reactive circuits

questions.label: E5A01
questions.text: What can cause the voltage across reactances in series to be larger than the voltage applied to them?
questions.answer: Resonance

questions.label: E5A02
questions.text: What is resonance in an electrical circuit?
distractors: The highest frequency that will pass current
The lowest frequency that will pass current
The frequency at which the reactive impedance equals the resistive impedance
questions.answer: The frequency at which the capacitive reactance equals the inductive reactance

questions.label: E5A03
questions.text: What is the magnitude of the impedance of a series RLC circuit at resonance?
distractors: High, as compared to the circuit resistance
questions.answer: Approximately equal to circuit resistance

questions.label: E5A04
questions.text: What is the magnitude of the impedance of a circuit with a resistor, an inductor and a capacitor all in parallel, at resonance?
distractors: Low, as compared to the circuit resistance
questions.answer: Approximately equal to circuit resistance

questions.label: E5A05
questions.text: What is the magnitude of the current at the input of a series RLC circuit as the frequency goes through resonance?
questions.answer: Maximum

questions.label: E5A06
questions.text: What is the magnitude of the circulating current within the components of a parallel LC circuit at resonance?
distractors: It equals 1 divided by the quantity 2 times Pi, multiplied by the square root of inductance L multiplied by capacitance C
It equals 2 multiplied by Pi, multiplied by frequency, multiplied by inductance
questions.answer: It is at a maximum

questions.label: E5A07
questions.text: What is the magnitude of the current at the input of a parallel RLC circuit at resonance?
questions.answer: Minimum

questions.label: E5A08
questions.text: What is the phase relationship between the current through and the voltage across a series resonant circuit at resonance?
distractors: The voltage leads the current by 90 degrees
The current leads the voltage by 90 degrees
The voltage and current are 180 degrees out of phase
questions.answer: The voltage and current are in phase

questions.label: E5A09
questions.text: How is the Q of an RLC parallel resonant circuit calculated?
distractors: Reactance of either the inductance or capacitance divided by the resistance
Reactance of either the inductance or capacitance multiplied by the resistance
Reactance of the inductance multiplied by the reactance of the capacitance
questions.answer: Resistance divided by the reactance of either the inductance or capacitance

questions.label: E5A10
questions.text: How is the Q of an RLC series resonant circuit calculated?
distractors: Reactance of either the inductance or capacitance times the resistance
Resistance divided by the reactance of either the inductance or capacitance
Reactance of the inductance times the reactance of the capacitance
questions.answer: Reactance of either the inductance or capacitance divided by the resistance

questions.label: E5A11
questions.text: What is the half-power bandwidth of a parallel resonant circuit that has a resonant frequency of 7.1 MHz and a Q of 150?
questions.answer: 47.3 kHz

questions.label: E5A12
questions.text: What is the half-power bandwidth of a parallel resonant circuit that has a resonant frequency of 3.7 MHz and a Q of 118?
questions.answer: 31.4 kHz

questions.label: E5A13
questions.text: What is an effect of increasing Q in a resonant circuit?
distractors: Fewer components are needed for the same performance
questions.answer: Internal voltages and circulating currents increase

questions.label: E5A14
questions.text: What is the resonant frequency of a series RLC circuit if R is 22 ohms, L is 50 microhenrys and C is 40 picofarads?
questions.answer: 3.56 MHz

questions.label: E5A15
questions.text: Which of the following can increase Q for inductors and capacitors?
questions.answer: Lower losses

questions.label: E5A16
questions.text: What is the resonant frequency of a parallel RLC circuit if R is 33 ohms, L is 50 microhenrys and C is 10 picofarads?
questions.answer: 7.12 MHz

questions.label: E5A17
questions.text: What is the result of increasing the Q of an impedance-matching circuit?
distractors: It has no effect on impedance matching
questions.answer: Matching bandwidth is decreased

subTopics.label: E5B
subTopics.description: Time constants and phase relationships: RLC time constants; definition; time constants in RL and RC circuits; phase angle between voltage and current; phase angles of series RLC; phase angle of inductance vs susceptance; admittance and susceptance

questions.label: E5B01
questions.text: What is the term for the time required for the capacitor in an RC circuit to be charged to 63.2% of the applied voltage?
questions.answer: One time constant

questions.label: E5B02
questions.text: What is the term for the time it takes for a charged capacitor in an RC circuit to discharge to 36.8% of its initial voltage?
distractors: An exponential discharge rate of one
questions.answer: One time constant

questions.label: E5B03
questions.text: What happens to the phase angle of a reactance when it is converted to a susceptance?
distractors: The susceptance phase angle is the inverse of the reactance phase angle
questions.answer: The sign is reversed

questions.label: E5B04
questions.text: What is the time constant of a circuit having two 220 microfarad capacitors and two 1 megohm resistors, all in parallel?
questions.answer: 220 seconds

questions.label: E5B05
questions.text: What happens to the magnitude of a reactance when it is converted to a susceptance?
questions.answer: The magnitude of the susceptance is the reciprocal of the magnitude of the reactance

questions.label: E5B06
questions.text: What is susceptance?
distractors: The magnetic impedance of a circuit
The ratio of magnetic field to electric field
A measure of the efficiency of a transformer
questions.answer: The inverse of reactance

questions.label: E5B07
questions.text: What is the phase angle between the voltage across and the current through a series RLC circuit if XC is 500 ohms, R is 1 kilohm, and XL is 250 ohms?
distractors: 68.2 degrees with the voltage leading the current
14.0 degrees with the voltage leading the current
68.2 degrees with the voltage lagging the current
questions.answer: 14.0 degrees with the voltage lagging the current

questions.label: E5B08
questions.text: What is the phase angle between the voltage across and the current through a series RLC circuit if XC is 100 ohms, R is 100 ohms, and XL is 75 ohms?
distractors: 14 degrees with the voltage leading the current
76 degrees with the voltage leading the current
76 degrees with the voltage lagging the current
questions.answer: 14 degrees with the voltage lagging the current

questions.label: E5B09
questions.text: What is the relationship between the current through a capacitor and the voltage across a capacitor?
distractors: Voltage and current are in phase
Voltage and current are 180 degrees out of phase
questions.answer: Current leads voltage by 90 degrees

questions.label: E5B10
questions.text: What is the relationship between the current through an inductor and the voltage across an inductor?
distractors: Voltage and current are 180 degrees out of phase
Voltage and current are in phase
questions.answer: Voltage leads current by 90 degrees

questions.label: E5B11
questions.text: What is the phase angle between the voltage across and the current through a series RLC circuit if XC is 25 ohms, R is 100 ohms, and XL is 50 ohms?
distractors: 14 degrees with the voltage lagging the current
76 degrees with the voltage lagging the current
76 degrees with the voltage leading the current
questions.answer: 14 degrees with the voltage leading the current

questions.label: E5B12
questions.text: What is admittance?
distractors: The term for the gain of a field effect transistor
The turns ratio of a transformer
The unit used for Q factor
questions.answer: The inverse of impedance

questions.label: E5B13
questions.text: What letter is commonly used to represent susceptance?
questions.answer: B

subTopics.label: E5C
subTopics.description: Coordinate systems and phasors in electronics: Rectangular Coordinates; Polar Coordinates; Phasors

questions.label: E5C01
questions.text: Which of the following represents a capacitive reactance in rectangular notation?
questions.answer: –jX

questions.label: E5C02
questions.text: How are impedances described in polar coordinates?
questions.answer: By phase angle and amplitude

questions.label: E5C03
questions.text: Which of the following represents an inductive reactance in polar coordinates?
questions.answer: A positive phase angle

questions.label: E5C04
questions.text: Which of the following represents a capacitive reactance in polar coordinates?
questions.answer: A negative phase angle

questions.label: E5C05
questions.text: What is the name of the diagram used to show the phase relationship between impedances at a given frequency?
questions.answer: Phasor diagram

questions.label: E5C06
questions.text: What does the impedance 50–j25 represent?
distractors: 50 ohms resistance in series with 25 ohms inductive reactance
25 ohms resistance in series with 50 ohms inductive reactance
25 ohms resistance in series with 50 ohms capacitive reactance
questions.answer: 50 ohms resistance in series with 25 ohms capacitive reactance

questions.label: E5C07
questions.text: What is a vector?
distractors: The value of a quantity that changes over time
The inverse of the tangent function
The inverse of the sine function
questions.answer: A quantity with both magnitude and an angular component

questions.label: E5C08
questions.text: What coordinate system is often used to display the phase angle of a circuit containing resistance, inductive and/or capacitive reactance?
questions.answer: Polar coordinates

questions.label: E5C09
questions.text: When using rectangular coordinates to graph the impedance of a circuit, what does the horizontal axis represent?
distractors: The sum of the reactive and resistive components
The difference between the resistive and reactive components
questions.answer: Resistive component

questions.label: E5C10
questions.text: When using rectangular coordinates to graph the impedance of a circuit, what does the vertical axis represent?
distractors: The sum of the reactive and resistive components
The difference between the resistive and reactive components
questions.answer: Reactive component

questions.label: E5C11
questions.text: What do the two numbers that are used to define a point on a graph using rectangular coordinates represent?
distractors: The magnitude and phase of the point
questions.answer: The coordinate values along the horizontal and vertical axes

questions.label: E5C12
questions.text: If you plot the impedance of a circuit using the rectangular coordinate system and find the impedance point falls on the right side of the graph on the horizontal axis, what do you know about the circuit?
distractors: It has to be a direct current circuit
It contains resistance and capacitive reactance
It contains resistance and inductive reactance
questions.answer: It is equivalent to a pure resistance

questions.label: E5C13
questions.text: What coordinate system is often used to display the resistive, inductive, and/or capacitive reactance components of impedance?
questions.answer: Rectangular coordinates

questions.label: E5C14
questions.text: Which point on Figure E5-2 best represents the impedance of a series circuit consisting of a 400 ohm resistor and a 38 picofarad capacitor at 14 MHz?
questions.answer: Point 4

questions.label: E5C15
questions.text: Which point in Figure E5-2 best represents the impedance of a series circuit consisting of a 300 ohm resistor and an 18 microhenry inductor at 3.505 MHz?
questions.answer: Point 3

questions.label: E5C16
questions.text: Which point on Figure E5-2 best represents the impedance of a series circuit consisting of a 300 ohm resistor and a 19 picofarad capacitor at 21.200 MHz?
questions.answer: Point 1

questions.label: E5C17
questions.text: Which point on Figure E5-2 best represents the impedance of a series circuit consisting of a 300 ohm resistor, a 0.64-microhenry inductor and an 85-picofarad capacitor at 24.900 MHz?
questions.answer: Point 8

subTopics.label: E5D
subTopics.description: AC and RF energy in real circuits: skin effect; electrostatic and electromagnetic fields; reactive power; power factor; electrical length of conductors at UHF and microwave frequencies

questions.label: E5D01
questions.text: What is the result of skin effect?
distractors: As frequency decreases, RF current flows in a thinner layer of the conductor, closer to the surface
Thermal effects on the surface of the conductor increase the impedance
Thermal effects on the surface of the conductor decrease the impedance
questions.answer: As frequency increases, RF current flows in a thinner layer of the conductor, closer to the surface

questions.label: E5D02
questions.text: Why is it important to keep lead lengths short for components used in circuits for VHF and above?
distractors: To increase the thermal time constant
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: To avoid unwanted inductive reactance

questions.label: E5D03
questions.text: What is microstrip?
distractors: Lightweight transmission line made of common zip cord
Miniature coax used for low power applications
Short lengths of coax mounted on printed circuit boards to minimize time delay between microwave circuits
questions.answer: Precision printed circuit conductors above a ground plane that provide constant impedance interconnects at microwave frequencies

questions.label: E5D04
questions.text: Why are short connections necessary at microwave frequencies?
questions.answer: To reduce phase shift along the connection

questions.label: E5D05
questions.text: Which parasitic characteristic increases with conductor length?
questions.answer: Inductance

questions.label: E5D06
questions.text: In what direction is the magnetic field oriented about a conductor in relation to the direction of electron flow?
distractors: In the same direction as the current
In a direction opposite to the current
questions.answer: In a direction determined by the left-hand rule

questions.label: E5D07
questions.text: What determines the strength of the magnetic field around a conductor?
distractors: The resistance divided by the current
The ratio of the current to the resistance
questions.answer: The amount of current flowing through the conductor

questions.label: E5D08
questions.text: What type of energy is stored in an electromagnetic or electrostatic field?
questions.answer: Potential energy

questions.label: E5D09
questions.text: What happens to reactive power in an AC circuit that has both ideal inductors and ideal capacitors?
distractors: It is dissipated as heat in the circuit
It is dissipated as kinetic energy in the circuit
It is dissipated in the formation of inductive and capacitive fields
questions.answer: It is repeatedly exchanged between the associated magnetic and electric fields, but is not dissipated

questions.label: E5D10
questions.text: How can the true power be determined in an AC circuit where the voltage and current are out of phase?
distractors: By dividing the reactive power by the power factor
By dividing the apparent power by the power factor
By multiplying the reactive power times the power factor
questions.answer: By multiplying the apparent power times the power factor

questions.label: E5D11
questions.text: What is the power factor of an R-L circuit having a 60 degree phase angle between the voltage and the current?

questions.label: E5D12
questions.text: How many watts are consumed in a circuit having a power factor of 0.2 if the input is 100-VAC at 4 amperes?
questions.answer: 80 watts

questions.label: E5D13
questions.text: How much power is consumed in a circuit consisting of a 100 ohm resistor in series with a 100 ohm inductive reactance drawing 1 ampere?
questions.answer: 100 Watts

questions.label: E5D14
questions.text: What is reactive power?
distractors: Power consumed in wire resistance in an inductor
Power lost because of capacitor leakage
questions.answer: Wattless, nonproductive power

questions.label: E5D15
questions.text: What is the power factor of an R-L circuit having a 45 degree phase angle between the voltage and the current?

questions.label: E5D16
questions.text: What is the power factor of an R-L circuit having a 30 degree phase angle between the voltage and the current?

questions.label: E5D17
questions.text: How many watts are consumed in a circuit having a power factor of 0.6 if the input is 200VAC at 5 amperes?
questions.answer: 600 watts

questions.label: E5D18
questions.text: How many watts are consumed in a circuit having a power factor of 0.71 if the apparent power is 500VA?

subTopics.label: E6A
subTopics.description: Semiconductor materials and devices: semiconductor materials; germanium, silicon, P-type, N-type; transistor types: NPN, PNP, junction, field-effect transistors: enhancement mode; depletion mode; MOS; CMOS; N-channel; P-channel

questions.label: E6A01
questions.text: In what application is gallium arsenide used as a semiconductor material in preference to germanium or silicon?
distractors: In very low frequency RF circuits
questions.answer: In microwave circuits

questions.label: E6A02
questions.text: Which of the following semiconductor materials contains excess free electrons?
questions.answer: N-type

questions.label: E6A03
questions.text: Why does a PN-junction diode not conduct current when reverse biased?
distractors: Only P-type semiconductor material can conduct current
Only N-type semiconductor material can conduct current
Excess holes in P-type material combine with the electrons in N-type material, converting the entire diode into an insulator
questions.answer: Holes in P-type material and electrons in the N-type material are separated by the applied voltage, widening the depletion region

questions.label: E6A04
questions.text: What is the name given to an impurity atom that adds holes to a semiconductor crystal structure?
questions.answer: Acceptor impurity

questions.label: E6A05
questions.text: What is the alpha of a bipolar junction transistor?
distractors: The change of collector current with respect to base current
The change of base current with respect to collector current
The change of collector current with respect to gate current
questions.answer: The change of collector current with respect to emitter current

questions.label: E6A06
questions.text: What is the beta of a bipolar junction transistor?
distractors: The frequency at which the current gain is reduced to 1
The breakdown voltage of the base to collector junction
The switching speed of the transistor
questions.answer: The change in collector current with respect to base current

questions.label: E6A07
questions.text: Which of the following indicates that a silicon NPN junction transistor is biased on?
distractors: Base-to-emitter resistance of approximately 6 to 7 ohms
Base-to-emitter resistance of approximately 0.6 to 0.7 ohms
Base-to-emitter voltage of approximately 6 to 7 volts
questions.answer: Base-to-emitter voltage of approximately 0.6 to 0.7 volts

questions.label: E6A08
questions.text: What term indicates the frequency at which the grounded-base current gain of a transistor has decreased to 0.7 of the gain obtainable at 1 kHz?
questions.answer: Alpha cutoff frequency

questions.label: E6A09
questions.text: What is a depletion-mode FET?
distractors: An FET that has no current flow between source and drain when no gate voltage is applied
Any FET for which holes are the majority carriers
questions.answer: An FET that exhibits a current flow between source and drain when no gate voltage is applied

questions.label: E6A10
questions.text: In Figure E6-2, what is the schematic symbol for an N-channel dual-gate MOSFET?

questions.label: E6A11
questions.text: In Figure E6-2, what is the schematic symbol for a P-channel junction FET?

questions.label: E6A12
questions.text: Why do many MOSFET devices have internally connected Zener diodes on the gates?
distractors: To provide a voltage reference for the correct amount of reverse-bias gate voltage
To protect the substrate from excessive voltages
To keep the gate voltage within specifications and prevent the device from overheating
questions.answer: To reduce the chance of the gate insulation being punctured by static discharges or excessive voltages

questions.label: E6A13
questions.text: What do the initials CMOS stand for?
questions.answer: Complementary Metal-Oxide Semiconductor

questions.label: E6A14
questions.text: How does DC input impedance at the gate of a field-effect transistor compare with the DC input impedance of a bipolar transistor?
distractors: An FET has low input impedance; a bipolar transistor has high input impedance
questions.answer: An FET has high input impedance; a bipolar transistor has low input impedance

questions.label: E6A15
questions.text: Which semiconductor material contains excess holes in the outer shell of electrons?
questions.answer: P-type

questions.label: E6A16
questions.text: What are the majority charge carriers in N-type semiconductor material?
questions.answer: Free electrons

questions.label: E6A17
questions.text: What are the names of the three terminals of a field-effect transistor?
questions.answer: Gate, drain, source

subTopics.label: E6B
subTopics.description: Diodes

questions.label: E6B01
questions.text: What is the most useful characteristic of a Zener diode?
distractors: A constant current drop under conditions of varying voltage
An internal capacitance that varies with the applied voltage
questions.answer: A constant voltage drop under conditions of varying current

questions.label: E6B02
questions.text: What is an important characteristic of a Schottky diode as compared to an ordinary silicon diode when used as a power supply rectifier?
questions.answer: Less forward voltage drop

questions.label: E6B03
questions.text: What special type of diode is capable of both amplification and oscillation?
questions.answer: Tunnel

questions.label: E6B04
questions.text: What type of semiconductor device is designed for use as a voltage-controlled capacitor?
questions.answer: Varactor diode

questions.label: E6B05
questions.text: What characteristic of a PIN diode makes it useful as an RF switch or attenuator?
distractors: Ability to dissipate large amounts of power
Reverse bias controls its forward voltage drop
questions.answer: A large region of intrinsic material

questions.label: E6B06
questions.text: Which of the following is a common use of a hot-carrier diode?
distractors: As balanced mixers in FM generation
As a variable capacitance in an automatic frequency control circuit
As a constant voltage reference in a power supply
questions.answer: As a VHF/UHF mixer or detector

questions.label: E6B07
questions.text: What is the failure mechanism when a junction diode fails due to excessive current?
questions.answer: Excessive junction temperature

questions.label: E6B08
questions.text: Which of the following describes a type of semiconductor diode?
questions.answer: Metal-semiconductor junction

questions.label: E6B09
questions.text: What is a common use for point contact diodes?
questions.answer: As an RF detector

questions.label: E6B10
questions.text: In Figure E6-3, what is the schematic symbol for a light-emitting diode?

questions.label: E6B11
questions.text: What is used to control the attenuation of RF signals by a PIN diode?
distractors: Reverse voltage larger than the RF signal
Capacitance of an RF coupling capacitor
questions.answer: Forward DC bias current

questions.label: E6B12
questions.text: What is one common use for PIN diodes?
questions.answer: As an RF switch

questions.label: E6B13
questions.text: What type of bias is required for an LED to emit light?
questions.answer: Forward bias

subTopics.label: E6C
subTopics.description: Digital ICs: Families of digital ICs; gates; Programmable Logic Devices (PLDs)

questions.label: E6C01
questions.text: What is the function of hysteresis in a comparator?
distractors: To allow the comparator to be used with AC input signals
To cause the output to change states continually
questions.answer: To prevent input noise from causing unstable output signals

questions.label: E6C02
questions.text: What happens when the level of a comparator’s input signal crosses the threshold?
distractors: The IC input can be damaged
questions.answer: The comparator changes its output state

questions.label: E6C03
questions.text: What is tri-state logic?
distractors: Logic devices that utilize ternary math
Low power logic devices designed to operate at 3 volts
Proprietary logic devices manufactured by Tri-State Devices
questions.answer: Logic devices with 0, 1, and high impedance output states

questions.label: E6C04
questions.text: What is the primary advantage of tri-state logic?
questions.answer: Ability to connect many device outputs to a common bus

questions.label: E6C05
questions.text: What is an advantage of CMOS logic devices over TTL devices?
distractors: Immune to damage from static discharge
questions.answer: Lower power consumption

questions.label: E6C06
questions.text: Why do CMOS digital integrated circuits have high immunity to noise on the input signal or power supply?
distractors: Larger bypass capacitors are used in CMOS circuit design
The input switching threshold is about two times the power supply voltage
questions.answer: The input switching threshold is about one-half the power supply voltage

questions.label: E6C07
questions.text: What best describes a pull-up or pull-down resistor?
distractors: A resistor in a keying circuit used to reduce key clicks
A resistor that insures that an oscillator frequency does not drive lower over time
A resistor connected to an op-amp output that only functions when the logic output is false
questions.answer: A resistor connected to the positive or negative supply line used to establish a voltage when an input or output is an open circuit

questions.label: E6C08
questions.text: In Figure E6-5, what is the schematic symbol for a NAND gate?

questions.label: E6C09
questions.text: What is a Programmable Logic Device (PLD)?
distractors: A device to control industrial equipment
Programmable equipment used for testing digital logic integrated circuits
An algorithm for simulating logic functions during circuit design
questions.answer: A programmable collection of logic gates and circuits in a single integrated circuit

questions.label: E6C10
questions.text: In Figure E6-5, what is the schematic symbol for a NOR gate?

questions.label: E6C11
questions.text: In Figure E6-5, what is the schematic symbol for the NOT operation (inverter)?

questions.label: E6C12
questions.text: What is BiCMOS logic?
distractors: A logic device with two CMOS circuits per package
A FET logic family based on bimetallic semiconductors
A logic family based on bismuth CMOS devices
questions.answer: An integrated circuit logic family using both bipolar and CMOS transistors

questions.label: E6C13
questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of BiCMOS logic?
distractors: Its simplicity results in much less expensive devices than standard CMOS
It is totally immune to electrostatic damage
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: It has the high input impedance of CMOS and the low output impedance of bipolar transistors

questions.label: E6C14
questions.text: What is the primary advantage of using a Programmable Gate Array (PGA) in a logic circuit?
distractors: Many similar gates are less expensive than a mixture of gate types
A PGA contains its own internal power supply
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Complex logic functions can be created in a single integrated circuit

subTopics.label: E6D
subTopics.description: Toroidal and Solenoidal Inductors: permeability, core material, selecting, winding; transformers; Piezoelectric devices

questions.label: E6D01
questions.text: How many turns will be required to produce a 5-microhenry inductor using a powdered-iron toroidal core that has an inductance index (A L) value of 40 microhenrys/100 turns?
questions.answer: 35 turns

questions.label: E6D02
questions.text: What is the equivalent circuit of a quartz crystal?
distractors: Motional capacitance, motional inductance, loss resistance, and a capacitor representing electrode and stray capacitance all in parallel
Motional capacitance, motional inductance, loss resistance, and a capacitor representing electrode and stray capacitance all in series
Motional inductance and loss resistance in series, paralleled with motional capacitance and a capacitor representing electrode and stray capacitance
questions.answer: Motional capacitance, motional inductance, and loss resistance in series, all in parallel with a shunt capacitor representing electrode and stray capacitance

questions.label: E6D03
questions.text: Which of the following is an aspect of the piezoelectric effect?
distractors: Mechanical deformation of material by the application of a magnetic field
Generation of electrical energy in the presence of light
Increased conductivity in the presence of light
questions.answer: Mechanical deformation of material by the application of a voltage

questions.label: E6D04
questions.text: Which materials are commonly used as a slug core in a variable inductor?
questions.answer: Ferrite and brass

questions.label: E6D05
questions.text: What is one reason for using ferrite cores rather than powdered-iron in an inductor?
distractors: Ferrite toroids generally have lower initial permeability
Ferrite toroids generally have better temperature stability
Ferrite toroids are easier to use with surface mount technology
questions.answer: Ferrite toroids generally require fewer turns to produce a given inductance value

questions.label: E6D06
questions.text: What core material property determines the inductance of a toroidal inductor?
questions.answer: Permeability

questions.label: E6D07
questions.text: What is the usable frequency range of inductors that use toroidal cores, assuming a correct selection of core material for the frequency being used?
distractors: From a few kHz to no more than 30 MHz
From approximately 10 Hz to no more than 3000 kHz
From about 100 kHz to at least 1000 GHz
questions.answer: From less than 20 Hz to approximately 300 MHz

questions.label: E6D08
questions.text: What is one reason for using powdered-iron cores rather than ferrite cores in an inductor?
distractors: Powdered-iron cores generally have greater initial permeability
Powdered-iron cores generally require fewer turns to produce a given inductance
Powdered-iron cores use smaller diameter wire for the same inductance
questions.answer: Powdered-iron cores generally maintain their characteristics at higher currents

questions.label: E6D09
questions.text: What devices are commonly used as VHF and UHF parasitic suppressors at the input and output terminals of a transistor HF amplifier?
questions.answer: Ferrite beads

questions.label: E6D10
questions.text: What is a primary advantage of using a toroidal core instead of a solenoidal core in an inductor?
distractors: Toroidal cores make it easier to couple the magnetic energy into other components
Toroidal cores have lower Q characteristics
questions.answer: Toroidal cores confine most of the magnetic field within the core material

questions.label: E6D11
questions.text: How many turns will be required to produce a 1-mH inductor using a core that has an inductance index (A L) value of 523 millihenrys/1000 turns?
questions.answer: 43 turns

questions.label: E6D12
questions.text: What is the definition of saturation in a ferrite core inductor?
distractors: The inductor windings are over coupled
The inductor’s voltage rating is exceeded causing a flashover
questions.answer: The ability of the inductor’s core to store magnetic energy has been exceeded

questions.label: E6D13
questions.text: What is the primary cause of inductor self-resonance?
questions.answer: Inter-turn capacitance

questions.label: E6D14
questions.text: Which type of slug material decreases inductance when inserted into a coil?
questions.answer: Brass

questions.label: E6D15
questions.text: What is current in the primary winding of a transformer called if no load is attached to the secondary?
questions.answer: Magnetizing current

questions.label: E6D16
questions.text: What is the common name for a capacitor connected across a transformer secondary that is used to absorb transient voltage spikes?
questions.answer: Snubber capacitor

questions.label: E6D17
questions.text: Why should core saturation of a conventional impedance matching transformer be avoided?
distractors: Magnetic flux would increase with frequency
Temporary changes of the core permeability could result
questions.answer: Harmonics and distortion could result

subTopics.label: E6E
subTopics.description: Analog ICs: MMICs, CCDs, Device packages

questions.label: E6E01
questions.text: Which of the following is true of a charge-coupled device (CCD)?
distractors: Its phase shift changes rapidly with frequency
It is a CMOS analog-to-digital converter
It is used in a battery charger circuit
questions.answer: It samples an analog signal and passes it in stages from the input to the output

questions.label: E6E02
questions.text: Which of the following device packages is a through-hole type?
questions.answer: DIP

questions.label: E6E03
questions.text: Which of the following materials is likely to provide the highest frequency of operation when used in MMICs?
questions.answer: Gallium nitride

questions.label: E6E04
questions.text: Which is the most common input and output impedance of circuits that use MMICs?
questions.answer: 50 ohms

questions.label: E6E05
questions.text: Which of the following noise figure values is typical of a low-noise UHF preamplifier?
questions.answer: 2 dB

questions.label: E6E06
questions.text: What characteristics of the MMIC make it a popular choice for VHF through microwave circuits?
distractors: The ability to retrieve information from a single signal even in the presence of other strong signals
Plate current that is controlled by a control grid
Nearly infinite gain, very high input impedance, and very low output impedance
questions.answer: Controlled gain, low noise figure, and constant input and output impedance over the specified frequency range

questions.label: E6E07
questions.text: Which of the following is typically used to construct a MMIC-based microwave amplifier?
questions.answer: Microstrip construction

questions.label: E6E08
questions.text: How is voltage from a power supply normally furnished to the most common type of monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC)?
distractors: Through a capacitor and RF choke connected to the amplifier input lead
Directly to the bias voltage (VCC IN) lead
questions.answer: Through a resistor and/or RF choke connected to the amplifier output lead

questions.label: E6E09
questions.text: Which of the following component package types would be most suitable for use at frequencies above the HF range?
questions.answer: Surface mount

questions.label: E6E10
questions.text: What is the packaging technique in which leadless components are soldered directly to circuit boards?
questions.answer: Surface mount

questions.label: E6E11
questions.text: What is a characteristic of DIP packaging used for integrated circuits?
distractors: Package mounts in a direct inverted position
Two chips in each package (Dual In Package)
questions.answer: A total of two rows of connecting pins placed on opposite sides of the package (Dual In-line Package)

questions.label: E6E12
questions.text: Why are high-power RF amplifier ICs and transistors sometimes mounted in ceramic packages?
distractors: To provide a low-pass frequency response
questions.answer: Better dissipation of heat

subTopics.label: E6F
subTopics.description: Optical components: photoconductive principles and effects, photovoltaic systems, optical couplers, optical sensors, and optoisolators; LCDs

questions.label: E6F01
questions.text: What is photoconductivity?
distractors: The conversion of photon energy to electromotive energy
The conversion of electromotive energy to photon energy
The decreased conductivity of an illuminated semiconductor
questions.answer: The increased conductivity of an illuminated semiconductor

questions.label: E6F02
questions.text: What happens to the conductivity of a photoconductive material when light shines on it?
questions.answer: It increases

questions.label: E6F03
questions.text: What is the most common configuration of an optoisolator or optocoupler?
questions.answer: An LED and a phototransistor

questions.label: E6F04
questions.text: What is the photovoltaic effect?
distractors: The conversion of voltage to current when exposed to light
The conversion of electrical energy to mechanical energy
The tendency of a battery to discharge when used outside
questions.answer: The conversion of light to electrical energy

questions.label: E6F05
questions.text: Which describes an optical shaft encoder?
distractors: A device which measures the strength of a beam of light using analog to digital conversion
A digital encryption device often used to encrypt spacecraft control signals
A device for generating RTTY signals by means of a rotating light source
questions.answer: A device which detects rotation of a control by interrupting a light source with a patterned wheel

questions.label: E6F06
questions.text: Which of these materials is affected the most by photoconductivity?
questions.answer: A crystalline semiconductor

questions.label: E6F07
questions.text: What is a solid state relay?
distractors: A relay using transistors to drive the relay coil
A mechanical relay that latches in the on or off state each time it is pulsed
questions.answer: A device that uses semiconductors to implement the functions of an electromechanical relay

questions.label: E6F08
questions.text: Why are optoisolators often used in conjunction with solid state circuits when switching 120VAC?
distractors: Optoisolators provide a low impedance link between a control circuit and a power circuit
Optoisolators provide impedance matching between the control circuit and power circuit
Optoisolators eliminate the effects of reflected light in the control circuit
questions.answer: Optoisolators provide a very high degree of electrical isolation between a control circuit and the circuit being switched

questions.label: E6F09
questions.text: What is the efficiency of a photovoltaic cell?
distractors: The output RF power divided by the input DC power
The open-circuit voltage divided by the short-circuit current under full illumination
questions.answer: The relative fraction of light that is converted to current

questions.label: E6F10
questions.text: What is the most common type of photovoltaic cell used for electrical power generation?
questions.answer: Silicon

questions.label: E6F11
questions.text: What is the approximate open-circuit voltage produced by a fully-illuminated silicon photovoltaic cell?

questions.label: E6F12
questions.text: What absorbs the energy from light falling on a photovoltaic cell?
questions.answer: Electrons

questions.label: E6F13
questions.text: What is a liquid crystal display (LCD)?
distractors: A modern replacement for a quartz crystal oscillator which displays its fundamental frequency
A frequency-determining unit for a transmitter or receiver
A display that uses a glowing liquid to remain brightly lit in dim light
questions.answer: A display utilizing a crystalline liquid and polarizing filters which becomes opaque when voltage is applied

questions.label: E6F14
questions.text: Which of the following is true of LCD displays?
distractors: They are hard to view in high ambient light conditions
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: They may be hard to view through polarized lenses

subTopics.label: E7A
subTopics.description: Digital circuits: digital circuit principles and logic circuits: classes of logic elements; positive and negative logic; frequency dividers; truth tables

questions.label: E7A01
questions.text: Which is a bi-stable circuit?
questions.answer: A flip-flop

questions.label: E7A02
questions.text: What is the function of a decade counter digital IC?
distractors: It decodes a decimal number for display on a seven segment LED display
It produces ten output pulses for every input pulse
It adds two decimal numbers together
questions.answer: It produces one output pulse for every ten input pulses

questions.label: E7A03
questions.text: Which of the following can divide the frequency of a pulse train by 2?
questions.answer: A flip-flop

questions.label: E7A04
questions.text: How many flip-flops are required to divide a signal frequency by 4?

questions.label: E7A05
questions.text: Which of the following is a circuit that continuously alternates between two states without an external clock?
questions.answer: Astable multivibrator

questions.label: E7A06
questions.text: What is a characteristic of a monostable multivibrator?
distractors: It produces a continuous square wave oscillating between 1 and 0
It stores one bit of data in either a 0 or 1 state
It maintains a constant output voltage, regardless of variations in the input voltage
questions.answer: It switches momentarily to the opposite binary state and then returns to its original state after a set time

questions.label: E7A07
questions.text: What logical operation does a NAND gate perform?
distractors: It produces logic "0" at its output only when all inputs are logic "0"
It produces logic "1" at its output only when all inputs are logic "1"
It produces logic "0" at its output if some but not all inputs are logic "1"
questions.answer: It produces logic "0" at its output only when all inputs are logic "1"

questions.label: E7A08
questions.text: What logical operation does an OR gate perform?
distractors: It produces logic "0" at its output if all inputs are logic "1"
It only produces logic "0" at its output when all inputs are logic "1"
It produces logic "1" at its output if all inputs are logic "0"
questions.answer: It produces logic "1" at its output if any or all inputs are logic "1"

questions.label: E7A09
questions.text: What logical operation is performed by an exclusive NOR gate?
distractors: It produces logic "0" at its output only if all inputs are logic "0"
It produces logic "1" at its output only if all inputs are logic "1"
It produces logic "1" at its output if any single input is logic "1"
questions.answer: It produces logic "0" at its output if any single input is logic "1"

questions.label: E7A10
questions.text: What is a truth table?
distractors: A table of logic symbols that indicate the high logic states of an op-amp
A diagram showing logic states when the digital device output is true
A table of logic symbols that indicate the logic states of an op-amp
questions.answer: A list of inputs and corresponding outputs for a digital device

questions.label: E7A11
questions.text: What type of logic defines "1" as a high voltage?
questions.answer: Positive Logic

questions.label: E7A12
questions.text: What type of logic defines "0" as a high voltage?
questions.answer: Negative logic

subTopics.label: E7B
subTopics.description: Amplifiers: Class of operation; vacuum tube and solid-state circuits; distortion and intermodulation; spurious and parasitic suppression; microwave amplifiers; switching-type amplifiers

questions.label: E7B01
questions.text: For what portion of a signal cycle does a Class AB amplifier operate?
questions.answer: More than 180 degrees but less than 360 degrees

questions.label: E7B02
questions.text: What is a Class D amplifier?
distractors: A low power amplifier that uses a differential amplifier for improved linearity
An amplifier that uses drift-mode FETs for high efficiency
questions.answer: A type of amplifier that uses switching technology to achieve high efficiency

questions.label: E7B03
questions.text: Which of the following components form the output of a class D amplifier circuit?
distractors: A high-pass filter to compensate for low gain at low frequencies
A matched load resistor to prevent damage by switching transients
A temperature compensating load resistor to improve linearity
questions.answer: A low-pass filter to remove switching signal components

questions.label: E7B04
questions.text: Where on the load line of a Class A common emitter amplifier would bias normally be set?
distractors: Where the load line intersects the voltage axis
At a point where the bias resistor equals the load resistor
At a point where the load line intersects the zero bias current curve
questions.answer: Approximately half-way between saturation and cutoff

questions.label: E7B05
questions.text: What can be done to prevent unwanted oscillations in an RF power amplifier?
distractors: Tune the stage for maximum SWR
Tune both the input and output for maximum power
Use a phase inverter in the output filter
questions.answer: Install parasitic suppressors and/or neutralize the stage

questions.label: E7B06
questions.text: Which of the following amplifier types reduces or eliminates even order harmonics?
questions.answer: Push-pull

questions.label: E7B07
questions.text: Which of the following is a likely result when a Class C amplifier is used to amplify a single-sideband phone signal?
questions.answer: Signal distortion and excessive bandwidth

questions.label: E7B08
questions.text: How can an RF power amplifier be neutralized?
distractors: By feeding an in-phase component of the output back to the input
questions.answer: By feeding a 180-degree out-of-phase portion of the output back to the input

questions.label: E7B09
questions.text: Which of the following describes how the loading and tuning capacitors are to be adjusted when tuning a vacuum tube RF power amplifier that employs a Pi-network output circuit?
distractors: The loading capacitor is set to maximum capacitance and the tuning capacitor is adjusted for minimum allowable plate current
The tuning capacitor is set to maximum capacitance and the loading capacitor is adjusted for minimum plate permissible current
The loading capacitor is adjusted to minimum plate current while alternately adjusting the tuning capacitor for maximum allowable plate current
questions.answer: The tuning capacitor is adjusted for minimum plate current, and the loading capacitor is adjusted for maximum permissible plate current

questions.label: E7B10
questions.text: In Figure E7-1, what is the purpose of R1 and R2?
questions.answer: Fixed bias

questions.label: E7B11
questions.text: In Figure E7-1, what is the purpose of R3?
questions.answer: Self bias

questions.label: E7B12
questions.text: What type of amplifier circuit is shown in Figure E7-1?
questions.answer: Common emitter

questions.label: E7B13
questions.text: In Figure E7-2, what is the purpose of R?
questions.answer: Emitter load

questions.label: E7B14
questions.text: Why are switching amplifiers more efficient than linear amplifiers?
distractors: Switching amplifiers operate at higher voltages
Linear amplifiers have high gain resulting in higher harmonic content
questions.answer: The power transistor is at saturation or cut off most of the time, resulting in low power dissipation

questions.label: E7B15
questions.text: What is one way to prevent thermal runaway in a bipolar transistor amplifier?
distractors: All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Use a resistor in series with the emitter

questions.label: E7B16
questions.text: What is the effect of intermodulation products in a linear power amplifier?
distractors: All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Transmission of spurious signals

questions.label: E7B17
questions.text: Why are odd-order rather than even-order intermodulation distortion products of concern in linear power amplifiers?
distractors: Because they are relatively far in frequency from the desired signal
Because they invert the sidebands causing distortion
Because they maintain the sidebands, thus causing multiple duplicate signals
questions.answer: Because they are relatively close in frequency to the desired signal

questions.label: E7B18
questions.text: What is a characteristic of a grounded-grid amplifier?
questions.answer: Low input impedance

subTopics.label: E7C
subTopics.description: Filters and matching networks: types of networks; types of filters; filter applications; filter characteristics; impedance matching; DSP filtering

questions.label: E7C01
questions.text: How are the capacitors and inductors of a low-pass filter Pi-network arranged between the network's input and output?
distractors: Two inductors are in series between the input and output, and a capacitor is connected between the two inductors and ground
Two capacitors are in series between the input and output, and an inductor is connected between the two capacitors and ground
An inductor is connected between the input and ground, another inductor is connected between the output and ground, and a capacitor is connected between the input and output
questions.answer: A capacitor is connected between the input and ground, another capacitor is connected between the output and ground, and an inductor is connected between input and output

questions.label: E7C02
questions.text: Which of the following is a property of a T-network with series capacitors and a parallel shunt inductor?
questions.answer: It is a high-pass filter

questions.label: E7C03
questions.text: What advantage does a Pi-L-network have over a regular Pi-network for impedance matching between the final amplifier of a vacuum-tube transmitter and an antenna?
questions.answer: Greater harmonic suppression

questions.label: E7C04
questions.text: How does an impedance-matching circuit transform a complex impedance to a resistive impedance?
distractors: It introduces negative resistance to cancel the resistive part of impedance
It introduces transconductance to cancel the reactive part of impedance
Network resistances are substituted for load resistances and reactances are matched to the resistances
questions.answer: It cancels the reactive part of the impedance and changes the resistive part to a desired value

questions.label: E7C05
questions.text: Which filter type is described as having ripple in the passband and a sharp cutoff?
questions.answer: A Chebyshev filter

questions.label: E7C06
questions.text: What are the distinguishing features of an elliptical filter?
distractors: Gradual passband rolloff with minimal stop band ripple
Extremely flat response over its pass band with gradually rounded stop band corners
Gradual passband rolloff with extreme stop band ripple
questions.answer: Extremely sharp cutoff with one or more notches in the stop band

questions.label: E7C07
questions.text: What kind of filter would you use to attenuate an interfering carrier signal while receiving an SSB transmission?
questions.answer: A notch filter

questions.label: E7C08
questions.text: Which of the following factors has the greatest effect in helping determine the bandwidth and response shape of a crystal ladder filter?
distractors: The DC voltage applied to the quartz crystal
The gain of the RF stage preceding the filter
The amplitude of the signals passing through the filter
questions.answer: The relative frequencies of the individual crystals

questions.label: E7C09
questions.text: What is a Jones filter as used as part of an HF receiver IF stage?
distractors: A special filter that emphasizes image responses
A filter that removes impulse noise
questions.answer: A variable bandwidth crystal lattice filter

questions.label: E7C10
questions.text: Which of the following filters would be the best choice for use in a 2 meter repeater duplexer?
questions.answer: A cavity filter

questions.label: E7C11
questions.text: Which of the following is the common name for a filter network which is equivalent to two L-networks connected back-to-back with the two inductors in series and the capacitors in shunt at the input and output?
questions.answer: Pi

questions.label: E7C12
questions.text: Which describes a Pi-L-network used for matching a vacuum tube final amplifier to a 50 ohm unbalanced output?
distractors: A network with only three discrete parts
A matching network in which all components are isolated from ground
questions.answer: A Pi-network with an additional series inductor on the output

questions.label: E7C13
questions.text: What is one advantage of a Pi-matching network over an L-matching network consisting of a single inductor and a single capacitor?
distractors: Pi-networks are designed for balanced input and output
questions.answer: The Q of Pi-networks can be varied depending on the component values chosen

questions.label: E7C14
questions.text: Which mode is most affected by non-linear phase response in a receiver IF filter?
questions.answer: Digital

questions.label: E7C15
questions.text: What is a crystal lattice filter?
distractors: A power supply filter made with interlaced quartz crystals
An audio filter made with four quartz crystals that resonate at 1kHz intervals
A filter with wide bandwidth and shallow skirts made using quartz crystals
questions.answer: A filter with narrow bandwidth and steep skirts made using quartz crystals

subTopics.label: E7D
subTopics.description: Power supplies and voltage regulators; Solar array charge controllers

questions.label: E7D01
questions.text: What is one characteristic of a linear electronic voltage regulator?
distractors: It has a ramp voltage as its output
It eliminates the need for a pass transistor
The control element duty cycle is proportional to the line or load conditions
questions.answer: The conduction of a control element is varied to maintain a constant output voltage

questions.label: E7D02
questions.text: What is one characteristic of a switching electronic voltage regulator?
distractors: The resistance of a control element is varied in direct proportion to the line voltage or load current
It is generally less efficient than a linear regulator
It gives a ramp voltage at its output
questions.answer: The controlled device’s duty cycle is changed to produce a constant average output voltage

questions.label: E7D03
questions.text: What device is typically used as a stable reference voltage in a linear voltage regulator?
questions.answer: A Zener diode

questions.label: E7D04
questions.text: Which of the following types of linear voltage regulator usually make the most efficient use of the primary power source?
questions.answer: A series regulator

questions.label: E7D05
questions.text: Which of the following types of linear voltage regulator places a constant load on the unregulated voltage source?
questions.answer: A shunt regulator

questions.label: E7D06
questions.text: What is the purpose of Q1 in the circuit shown in Figure E7-3?
distractors: It provides negative feedback to improve regulation
It provides a constant load for the voltage source
questions.answer: It increases the current-handling capability of the regulator

questions.label: E7D07
questions.text: What is the purpose of C2 in the circuit shown in Figure E7-3?
distractors: It is a brute force filter for the output
To self-resonate at the hum frequency
To provide fixed DC bias for Q1
questions.answer: It bypasses hum around D1

questions.label: E7D08
questions.text: What type of circuit is shown in Figure E7-3?
questions.answer: Linear voltage regulator

questions.label: E7D09
questions.text: What is the main reason to use a charge controller with a solar power system?
distractors: Control of electrolyte levels during battery discharge
Matching of day and night charge rates
questions.answer: Prevention of battery damage due to overcharge

questions.label: E7D10
questions.text: What is the primary reason that a high-frequency switching type high voltage power supply can be both less expensive and lighter in weight than a conventional power supply?
distractors: The inverter design does not require any output filtering
It uses a diode bridge rectifier for increased output
It uses a large power factor compensation capacitor to create free power from the unused portion of the AC cycle
questions.answer: The high frequency inverter design uses much smaller transformers and filter components for an equivalent power output

questions.label: E7D11
questions.text: What circuit element is controlled by a series analog voltage regulator to maintain a constant output voltage?
questions.answer: Pass transistor

questions.label: E7D12
questions.text: What is the drop-out voltage of an analog voltage regulator?
distractors: Minimum input voltage for rated power dissipation
Maximum amount that the output voltage drops when the input voltage is varied over its specified range
Maximum amount that the output voltage may decrease at rated load
questions.answer: Minimum input-to-output voltage required to maintain regulation

questions.label: E7D13
questions.text: What is the equation for calculating power dissipation by a series connected linear voltage regulator?
distractors: Input voltage multiplied by input current
Input voltage divided by output current
Output voltage multiplied by output current
questions.answer: Voltage difference from input to output multiplied by output current

questions.label: E7D14
questions.text: What is one purpose of a "bleeder" resistor in a conventional unregulated power supply?
distractors: To cut down on waste heat generated by the power supply
To balance the low-voltage filament windings
To boost the amount of output current
questions.answer: To improve output voltage regulation

questions.label: E7D15
questions.text: What is the purpose of a "step-start" circuit in a high voltage power supply?
distractors: To provide a dual-voltage output for reduced power applications
To compensate for variations of the incoming line voltage
To allow for remote control of the power supply
questions.answer: To allow the filter capacitors to charge gradually

questions.label: E7D16
questions.text: When several electrolytic filter capacitors are connected in series to increase the operating voltage of a power supply filter circuit, why should resistors be connected across each capacitor?
distractors: To equalize, as much as possible, the voltage drop across each capacitor
To provide a safety bleeder to discharge the capacitors when the supply is off
To provide a minimum load current to reduce voltage excursions at light loads
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

subTopics.label: E7E
subTopics.description: Modulation and demodulation: reactance, phase and balanced modulators; detectors; mixer stages

questions.label: E7E01
questions.text: Which of the following can be used to generate FM phone emissions?
distractors: A balanced modulator on the audio amplifier
A reactance modulator on the final amplifier
A balanced modulator on the oscillator
questions.answer: A reactance modulator on the oscillator

questions.label: E7E02
questions.text: What is the function of a reactance modulator?
distractors: To produce PM signals by using an electrically variable resistance
To produce AM signals by using an electrically variable inductance or capacitance
To produce AM signals by using an electrically variable resistance
questions.answer: To produce PM signals by using an electrically variable inductance or capacitance

questions.label: E7E03
questions.text: How does an analog phase modulator function?
distractors: By varying the tuning of a microphone preamplifier to produce PM signals
By varying the tuning of an amplifier tank circuit to produce AM signals
By varying the tuning of a microphone preamplifier to produce AM signals
questions.answer: By varying the tuning of an amplifier tank circuit to produce PM signals

questions.label: E7E04
questions.text: What is one way a single-sideband phone signal can be generated?
distractors: By using a reactance modulator followed by a mixer
By using a loop modulator followed by a mixer
By driving a product detector with a DSB signal
questions.answer: By using a balanced modulator followed by a filter

questions.label: E7E05
questions.text: What circuit is added to an FM transmitter to boost the higher audio frequencies?
questions.answer: A pre-emphasis network

questions.label: E7E06
questions.text: Why is de-emphasis commonly used in FM communications receivers?
questions.answer: For compatibility with transmitters using phase modulation

questions.label: E7E07
questions.text: What is meant by the term baseband in radio communications?
distractors: The lowest frequency band that the transmitter or receiver covers
The unmodulated bandwidth of the transmitted signal
The basic oscillator frequency in an FM transmitter that is multiplied to increase the deviation and carrier frequency
questions.answer: The frequency components present in the modulating signal

questions.label: E7E08
questions.text: What are the principal frequencies that appear at the output of a mixer circuit?
distractors: Two and four times the original frequency
The sum, difference and square root of the input frequencies
questions.answer: The two input frequencies along with their sum and difference frequencies

questions.label: E7E09
questions.text: What occurs when an excessive amount of signal energy reaches a mixer circuit?
questions.answer: Spurious mixer products are generated

questions.label: E7E10
questions.text: How does a diode detector function?
distractors: By breakdown of the Zener voltage
By mixing signals with noise in the transition region of the diode
By sensing the change of reactance in the diode with respect to frequency
questions.answer: By rectification and filtering of RF signals

questions.label: E7E11
questions.text: Which type of detector is used for demodulating SSB signals?
questions.answer: Product detector

questions.label: E7E12
questions.text: What is a frequency discriminator stage in a FM receiver?
distractors: A circuit for filtering two closely adjacent signals
questions.answer: A circuit for detecting FM signals

subTopics.label: E7F
subTopics.description: DSP filtering and other operations; Software Defined Radio Fundamentals; DSP modulation and demodulation

questions.label: E7F01
questions.text: What is meant by direct digital conversion as applied to software defined radios?
distractors: Software is converted from source code to object code during operation of the receiver
Incoming RF is converted to a control voltage for a voltage controlled oscillator
A switching mixer is used to generate I and Q signals directly from the RF input
questions.answer: Incoming RF is digitized by an analog-to-digital converter without being mixed with a local oscillator signal

questions.label: E7F02
questions.text: What kind of digital signal processing audio filter is used to remove unwanted noise from a received SSB signal?
questions.answer: An adaptive filter

questions.label: E7F03
questions.text: What type of digital signal processing filter is used to generate an SSB signal?
questions.answer: A Hilbert-transform filter

questions.label: E7F04
questions.text: What is a common method of generating an SSB signal using digital signal processing?
distractors: Mixing products are converted to voltages and subtracted by adder circuits
A frequency synthesizer removes the unwanted sidebands
Emulation of quartz crystal filter characteristics
questions.answer: Combine signals with a quadrature phase relationship

questions.label: E7F05
questions.text: How frequently must an analog signal be sampled by an analog-to-digital converter so that the signal can be accurately reproduced?
distractors: At half the rate of the highest frequency component of the signal
At the same rate as the highest frequency component of the signal
At four times the rate of the highest frequency component of the signal
questions.answer: At twice the rate of the highest frequency component of the signal

questions.label: E7F06
questions.text: What is the minimum number of bits required for an analog-to-digital converter to sample a signal with a range of 1 volt at a resolution of 1 millivolt?
questions.answer: 10 bits

questions.label: E7F07
questions.text: What function can a Fast Fourier Transform perform?
distractors: Converting analog signals to digital form
Converting digital signals to analog form
questions.answer: Converting digital signals from the time domain to the frequency domain

questions.label: E7F08
questions.text: What is the function of decimation with regard to digital filters?
distractors: Converting data to binary code decimal form
questions.answer: Reducing the effective sample rate by removing samples

questions.label: E7F09
questions.text: Why is an anti-aliasing digital filter required in a digital decimator?
distractors: It peaks the response of the decimator, improving bandwidth
It removes low frequency signal components to eliminate the need for DC restoration
It notches out the sampling frequency to avoid sampling errors
questions.answer: It removes high-frequency signal components which would otherwise be reproduced as lower frequency components

questions.label: E7F10
questions.text: What aspect of receiver analog-to-digital conversion determines the maximum receive bandwidth of a Direct Digital Conversion SDR?
questions.answer: Sample rate

questions.label: E7F11
questions.text: What sets the minimum detectable signal level for an SDR in the absence of atmospheric or thermal noise?
questions.answer: Reference voltage level and sample width in bits

questions.label: E7F12
questions.text: What digital process is applied to I and Q signals in order to recover the baseband modulation information?
questions.answer: Fast Fourier Transform

questions.label: E7F13
questions.text: What is the function of taps in a digital signal processing filter?
distractors: To reduce excess signal pressure levels
Select the point at which baseband signals are generated
questions.answer: Provide incremental signal delays for filter algorithms

questions.label: E7F14
questions.text: Which of the following would allow a digital signal processing filter to create a sharper filter response?
questions.answer: More taps

questions.label: E7F15
questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of a Finite Impulse Response (FIR) filter vs an Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) digital filter?
distractors: FIR filters are easier to implement for a given set of passband rolloff requirements
FIR filters can respond faster to impulses
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: FIR filters delay all frequency components of the signal by the same amount

questions.label: E7F16
questions.text: How might the sampling rate of an existing digital signal be adjusted by a factor of 3/4?
distractors: Change the gain by a factor of 3/4
Multiply each sample value by a factor of 3/4
Add 3 to each input value and subtract 4 from each output value
questions.answer: Interpolate by a factor of three, then decimate by a factor of four

questions.label: E7F17
questions.text: What do the letters I and Q in I/Q Modulation represent?
questions.answer: In-phase and Quadrature

subTopics.label: E7G
subTopics.description: Active filters and op-amp circuits: active audio filters; characteristics; basic circuit design; operational amplifiers

questions.label: E7G01
questions.text: What is the typical output impedance of an integrated circuit op-amp?
questions.answer: Very low

questions.label: E7G02
questions.text: What is the effect of ringing in a filter?
distractors: An echo caused by a long time delay
A reduction in high frequency response
Partial cancellation of the signal over a range of frequencies
questions.answer: Undesired oscillations added to the desired signal

questions.label: E7G03
questions.text: What is the typical input impedance of an integrated circuit op-amp?
questions.answer: Very high

questions.label: E7G04
questions.text: What is meant by the term op-amp input offset voltage?
distractors: The output voltage of the op-amp minus its input voltage
The difference between the output voltage of the op-amp and the input voltage required in the immediately following stage
The potential between the amplifier input terminals of the op-amp in an open loop condition
questions.answer: The differential input voltage needed to bring the open loop output voltage to zero

questions.label: E7G05
questions.text: How can unwanted ringing and audio instability be prevented in a multi-section op-amp RC audio filter circuit?
questions.answer: Restrict both gain and Q

questions.label: E7G06
questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate use of an op-amp active filter?
distractors: As a high-pass filter used to block RFI at the input to receivers
As a low-pass filter used between a transmitter and a transmission line
questions.answer: As an audio filter in a receiver

questions.label: E7G07
questions.text: What magnitude of voltage gain can be expected from the circuit in Figure E7-4 when R1 is 10 ohms and RF is 470 ohms?

questions.label: E7G08
questions.text: How does the gain of an ideal operational amplifier vary with frequency?
distractors: It increases linearly with increasing frequency
It decreases linearly with increasing frequency
It decreases logarithmically with increasing frequency
questions.answer: It does not vary with frequency

questions.label: E7G09
questions.text: What will be the output voltage of the circuit shown in Figure E7-4 if R1 is 1000 ohms, RF is 10,000 ohms, and 0.23 volts DC is applied to the input?
questions.answer: -2.3 volts

questions.label: E7G10
questions.text: What absolute voltage gain can be expected from the circuit in Figure E7-4 when R1 is 1800 ohms and RF is 68 kilohms?

questions.label: E7G11
questions.text: What absolute voltage gain can be expected from the circuit in Figure E7-4 when R1 is 3300 ohms and RF is 47 kilohms?

questions.label: E7G12
questions.text: What is an integrated circuit operational amplifier?
distractors: A digital audio amplifier whose characteristics are determined by components external to the amplifier
An amplifier used to increase the average output of frequency modulated amateur signals to the legal limit
A RF amplifier used in the UHF and microwave regions
questions.answer: A high-gain, direct-coupled differential amplifier with very high input impedance and very low output impedance

subTopics.label: E7H
subTopics.description: Oscillators and signal sources: types of oscillators; synthesizers and phase-locked loops; direct digital synthesizers; stabilizing thermal drift; microphonics; high accuracy oscillators

questions.label: E7H01
questions.text: What are three oscillator circuits used in Amateur Radio equipment?
questions.answer: Colpitts, Hartley and Pierce

questions.label: E7H02
questions.text: Which describes a microphonic?
distractors: An IC used for amplifying microphone signals
Distortion caused by RF pickup on the microphone cable
Excess loading of the microphone by an oscillator
questions.answer: Changes in oscillator frequency due to mechanical vibration

questions.label: E7H03
