questions.text: How is positive feedback supplied in a Hartley oscillator?
questions.answer: Through a tapped coil

questions.label: E7H04
questions.text: How is positive feedback supplied in a Colpitts oscillator?
questions.answer: Through a capacitive divider

questions.label: E7H05
questions.text: How is positive feedback supplied in a Pierce oscillator?
questions.answer: Through a quartz crystal

questions.label: E7H06
questions.text: Which of the following oscillator circuits are commonly used in VFOs?
questions.answer: Colpitts and Hartley

questions.label: E7H07
questions.text: How can an oscillator’s microphonic responses be reduced?
distractors: Eliminating noise on the oscillator’s power supply
Using the oscillator only for CW and digital signals
questions.answer: Mechanically isolating the oscillator circuitry from its enclosure

questions.label: E7H08
questions.text: Which of the following components can be used to reduce thermal drift in crystal oscillators?
questions.answer: NP0 capacitors

questions.label: E7H09
questions.text: What type of frequency synthesizer circuit uses a phase accumulator, lookup table, digital to analog converter, and a low-pass anti-alias filter?
questions.answer: A direct digital synthesizer

questions.label: E7H10
questions.text: What information is contained in the lookup table of a direct digital frequency synthesizer?
distractors: The phase relationship between a reference oscillator and the output waveform
The phase relationship between a voltage-controlled oscillator and the output waveform
The synthesizer frequency limits and frequency values stored in the radio memories
questions.answer: The amplitude values that represent a sine-wave output

questions.label: E7H11
questions.text: What are the major spectral impurity components of direct digital synthesizers?
questions.answer: Spurious signals at discrete frequencies

questions.label: E7H12
questions.text: Which of the following must be done to insure that a crystal oscillator provides the frequency specified by the crystal manufacturer?
distractors: Provide the crystal with a specified parallel inductance
Bias the crystal at a specified voltage
Bias the crystal at a specified current
questions.answer: Provide the crystal with a specified parallel capacitance

questions.label: E7H13
questions.text: Which of the following is a technique for providing highly accurate and stable oscillators needed for microwave transmission and reception?
distractors: Use a rubidium stabilized reference oscillator
Use a temperature-controlled high Q dielectric resonator
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E7H14
questions.text: What is a phase-locked loop circuit?
distractors: An electronic servo loop consisting of a ratio detector, reactance modulator, and voltage-controlled oscillator
An electronic circuit also known as a monostable multivibrator
An electronic circuit consisting of a precision push-pull amplifier with a differential input
questions.answer: An electronic servo loop consisting of a phase detector, a low-pass filter, a voltage-controlled oscillator, and a stable reference oscillator

questions.label: E7H15
questions.text: Which of these functions can be performed by a phase-locked loop?
distractors: Wide-band AF and RF power amplification
Comparison of two digital input signals, digital pulse counter
questions.answer: Frequency synthesis, FM demodulation

subTopics.label: E8A
subTopics.description: AC waveforms: sine, square, sawtooth and irregular waveforms; AC measurements; average and PEP of RF signals; Fourier analysis; Analog to digital conversion: Digital to Analog conversion

questions.label: E8A01
questions.text: What is the name of the process that shows that a square wave is made up of a sine wave plus all of its odd harmonics?
questions.answer: Fourier analysis

questions.label: E8A02
questions.text: What type of wave has a rise time significantly faster than its fall time (or vice versa)?
questions.answer: A sawtooth wave

questions.label: E8A03
questions.text: What type of wave does a Fourier analysis show to be made up of sine waves of a given fundamental frequency plus all of its harmonics?
questions.answer: A sawtooth wave

questions.label: E8A04
questions.text: What is "dither" with respect to analog to digital converters?
distractors: An abnormal condition where the converter cannot settle on a value to represent the signal
An error caused by irregular quantization step size
A method of decimation by randomly skipping samples
questions.answer: A small amount of noise added to the input signal to allow more precise representation of a signal over time

questions.label: E8A05
questions.text: What would be the most accurate way of measuring the RMS voltage of a complex waveform?
distractors: By using a grid dip meter
By measuring the voltage with a D'Arsonval meter
By using an absorption wave meter
questions.answer: By measuring the heating effect in a known resistor

questions.label: E8A06
questions.text: What is the approximate ratio of PEP-to-average power in a typical single-sideband phone signal?

questions.label: E8A07
questions.text: What determines the PEP-to-average power ratio of a single-sideband phone signal?
distractors: The frequency of the modulating signal
questions.answer: The characteristics of the modulating signal

questions.label: E8A08
questions.text: Why would a direct or flash conversion analog-to-digital converter be useful for a software defined radio?
distractors: Very low power consumption decreases frequency drift
Immunity to out of sequence coding reduces spurious responses
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Very high speed allows digitizing high frequencies

questions.label: E8A09
questions.text: How many levels can an analog-to-digital converter with 8 bit resolution encode?
distractors: 8 multiplied by the gain of the input amplifier
256 divided by the gain of the input amplifier

questions.label: E8A10
questions.text: What is the purpose of a low pass filter used in conjunction with a digital-to-analog converter?
distractors: Lower the input bandwidth to increase the effective resolution
Improve accuracy by removing out of sequence codes from the input
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Remove harmonics from the output caused by the discrete analog levels generated

questions.label: E8A11
questions.text: What type of information can be conveyed using digital waveforms?
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E8A12
questions.text: What is an advantage of using digital signals instead of analog signals to convey the same information?
distractors: Less complex circuitry is required for digital signal generation and detection
Digital signals always occupy a narrower bandwidth
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Digital signals can be regenerated multiple times without error

questions.label: E8A13
questions.text: Which of these methods is commonly used to convert analog signals to digital signals?
questions.answer: Sequential sampling

subTopics.label: E8B
subTopics.description: Modulation and demodulation: modulation methods; modulation index and deviation ratio; frequency and time division multiplexing; Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing

questions.label: E8B01
questions.text: What is the term for the ratio between the frequency deviation of an RF carrier wave and the modulating frequency of its corresponding FM-phone signal?
questions.answer: Modulation index

questions.label: E8B02
questions.text: How does the modulation index of a phase-modulated emission vary with RF carrier frequency (the modulated frequency)?
distractors: It increases as the RF carrier frequency increases
It decreases as the RF carrier frequency increases
It varies with the square root of the RF carrier frequency
questions.answer: It does not depend on the RF carrier frequency

questions.label: E8B03
questions.text: What is the modulation index of an FM-phone signal having a maximum frequency deviation of 3000 Hz either side of the carrier frequency when the modulating frequency is 1000 Hz?

questions.label: E8B04
questions.text: What is the modulation index of an FM-phone signal having a maximum carrier deviation of plus or minus 6 kHz when modulated with a 2 kHz modulating frequency?

questions.label: E8B05
questions.text: What is the deviation ratio of an FM-phone signal having a maximum frequency swing of plus-or-minus 5 kHz when the maximum modulation frequency is 3 kHz?

questions.label: E8B06
questions.text: What is the deviation ratio of an FM-phone signal having a maximum frequency swing of plus or minus 7.5 kHz when the maximum modulation frequency is 3.5 kHz?

questions.label: E8B07
questions.text: Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing is a technique used for which type of amateur communication?
distractors: OFDM signals are not allowed on amateur bands
questions.answer: High speed digital modes

questions.label: E8B08
questions.text: What describes Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing?
distractors: A frequency modulation technique which uses non-harmonically related frequencies
A bandwidth compression technique using Fourier transforms
A digital mode for narrow band, slow speed transmissions
questions.answer: A digital modulation technique using subcarriers at frequencies chosen to avoid intersymbol interference

questions.label: E8B09
questions.text: What is meant by deviation ratio?
distractors: The ratio of the audio modulating frequency to the center carrier frequency
The ratio of the carrier center frequency to the audio modulating frequency
The ratio of the highest audio modulating frequency to the average audio modulating frequency
questions.answer: The ratio of the maximum carrier frequency deviation to the highest audio modulating frequency

questions.label: E8B10
questions.text: What describes frequency division multiplexing?
distractors: The transmitted signal jumps from band to band at a predetermined rate
The transmitted signal is divided into packets of information
Two or more information streams are merged into a digital combiner, which then pulse position modulates the transmitter
questions.answer: Two or more information streams are merged into a baseband, which then modulates the transmitter

questions.label: E8B11
questions.text: What is digital time division multiplexing?
distractors: Two or more data streams are assigned to discrete sub-carriers on an FM transmitter
Two or more data streams share the same channel by transmitting time of transmission as the sub-carrier
Two or more signals are quadrature modulated to increase bandwidth efficiency
questions.answer: Two or more signals are arranged to share discrete time slots of a data transmission

subTopics.label: E8C
subTopics.description: Digital signals: digital communication modes; information rate vs bandwidth; error correction

questions.label: E8C01
questions.text: How is Forward Error Correction implemented?
distractors: By the receiving station repeating each block of three data characters
By transmitting a special algorithm to the receiving station along with the data characters
By varying the frequency shift of the transmitted signal according to a predefined algorithm
questions.answer: By transmitting extra data that may be used to detect and correct transmission errors

questions.label: E8C02
questions.text: What is the definition of symbol rate in a digital transmission?
distractors: The number of control characters in a message packet
The duration of each bit in a message sent over the air
The number of characters carried per second by the station-to-station link
questions.answer: The rate at which the waveform of a transmitted signal changes to convey information

questions.label: E8C03
questions.text: When performing phase shift keying, why is it advantageous to shift phase precisely at the zero crossing of the RF carrier?
distractors: It is easier to demodulate with a conventional, non-synchronous detector
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: This results in the least possible transmitted bandwidth for the particular mode

questions.label: E8C04
questions.text: What technique is used to minimize the bandwidth requirements of a PSK31 signal?
questions.answer: Use of sinusoidal data pulses

questions.label: E8C05
questions.text: What is the necessary bandwidth of a 13-WPM International Morse code transmission?
questions.answer: Approximately 52 Hz

questions.label: E8C06
questions.text: What is the necessary bandwidth of a 170-hertz shift, 300-baud ASCII transmission?
questions.answer: 0.5 kHz

questions.label: E8C07
questions.text: What is the necessary bandwidth of a 4800-Hz frequency shift, 9600-baud ASCII FM transmission?

questions.label: E8C08
questions.text: How does ARQ accomplish error correction?
distractors: Special binary codes provide automatic correction
Special polynomial codes provide automatic correction
If errors are detected, redundant data is substituted
questions.answer: If errors are detected, a retransmission is requested

questions.label: E8C09
questions.text: Which is the name of a digital code where each preceding or following character changes by only one bit?
distractors: Extended Binary Coded Decimal Interchange Code
questions.answer: Gray code

questions.label: E8C10
questions.text: What is an advantage of Gray code in digital communications where symbols are transmitted as multiple bits?
distractors: It has more possible states than simple binary
It has more resolution than simple binary
questions.answer: It facilitates error detection

questions.label: E8C11
questions.text: What is the relationship between symbol rate and baud?
distractors: Baud is twice the symbol rate
Symbol rate is only used for packet-based modes
Baud is only used for RTTY
questions.answer: They are the same

subTopics.label: E8D
subTopics.description: Keying defects and overmodulation of digital signals; digital codes; spread spectrum

questions.label: E8D01
questions.text: Why are received spread spectrum signals resistant to interference?
distractors: The high power used by a spread spectrum transmitter keeps its signal from being easily overpowered
The receiver is always equipped with a digital blanker
If interference is detected by the receiver it will signal the transmitter to change frequencies
questions.answer: Signals not using the spread spectrum algorithm are suppressed in the receiver

questions.label: E8D02
questions.text: What spread spectrum communications technique uses a high speed binary bit stream to shift the phase of an RF carrier?
questions.answer: Direct sequence

questions.label: E8D03
questions.text: How does the spread spectrum technique of frequency hopping work?
distractors: If interference is detected by the receiver it will signal the transmitter to change frequencies
If interference is detected by the receiver it will signal the transmitter to wait until the frequency is clear
A pseudo-random binary bit stream is used to shift the phase of an RF carrier very rapidly in a particular sequence
questions.answer: The frequency of the transmitted signal is changed very rapidly according to a particular sequence also used by the receiving station

questions.label: E8D04
questions.text: What is the primary effect of extremely short rise or fall time on a CW signal?
questions.answer: The generation of key clicks

questions.label: E8D05
questions.text: What is the most common method of reducing key clicks?
distractors: Low-pass filters at the transmitter output
Reduce keying waveform rise and fall times
High-pass filters at the transmitter output
questions.answer: Increase keying waveform rise and fall times

questions.label: E8D06
questions.text: Which of the following indicates likely overmodulation of an AFSK signal such as PSK or MFSK?
questions.answer: Strong ALC action

questions.label: E8D07
questions.text: What is a common cause of overmodulation of AFSK signals?
questions.answer: Excessive transmit audio levels

questions.label: E8D08
questions.text: What parameter might indicate that excessively high input levels are causing distortion in an AFSK signal?
questions.answer: Intermodulation Distortion (IMD)

questions.label: E8D09
questions.text: What is considered a good minimum IMD level for an idling PSK signal?
questions.answer: -30 dB

questions.label: E8D10
questions.text: What are some of the differences between the Baudot digital code and ASCII?
distractors: Baudot uses 4 data bits per character, ASCII uses 7 or 8; Baudot uses 1 character as a letters/figures shift code, ASCII has no letters/figures code
Baudot uses 6 data bits per character, ASCII uses 7 or 8; Baudot has no letters/figures shift code, ASCII uses 2 letters/figures shift codes
Baudot uses 7 data bits per character, ASCII uses 8; Baudot has no letters/figures shift code, ASCII uses 2 letters/figures shift codes
questions.answer: Baudot uses 5 data bits per character, ASCII uses 7 or 8; Baudot uses 2 characters as letters/figures shift codes, ASCII has no letters/figures shift code

questions.label: E8D11
questions.text: What is one advantage of using ASCII code for data communications?
distractors: It includes built in error correction features
It contains fewer information bits per character than any other code
It uses one character as a shift code to send numeric and special characters
questions.answer: It is possible to transmit both upper and lower case text

questions.label: E8D12
questions.text: What is the advantage of including a parity bit with an ASCII character stream?
distractors: The signal can overpower interfering signals
Foreign language characters can be sent
questions.answer: Some types of errors can be detected

subTopics.label: E9A
subTopics.description: Basic Antenna parameters: radiation resistance, gain, beamwidth, efficiency, beamwidth; effective radiated power, polarization

questions.label: E9A01
questions.text: What describes an isotropic antenna?
distractors: A grounded antenna used to measure earth conductivity
A horizontally polarized antenna used to compare Yagi antennas
A spacecraft antenna used to direct signals toward the earth
questions.answer: A theoretical antenna used as a reference for antenna gain

questions.label: E9A02
questions.text: What antenna has no gain in any direction?
questions.answer: Isotropic antenna

questions.label: E9A03
questions.text: Why would one need to know the feed point impedance of an antenna?
distractors: To measure the near-field radiation density from a transmitting antenna
To calculate the front-to-side ratio of the antenna
To calculate the front-to-back ratio of the antenna
questions.answer: To match impedances in order to minimize standing wave ratio on the transmission line

questions.label: E9A04
questions.text: Which of the following factors may affect the feed point impedance of an antenna?
distractors: The settings of an antenna tuner at the transmitter
Sunspot activity and time of day
questions.answer: Antenna height, conductor length/diameter ratio and location of nearby conductive objects

questions.label: E9A05
questions.text: What is included in the total resistance of an antenna system?
questions.answer: Radiation resistance plus ohmic resistance

questions.label: E9A06
questions.text: How does the beamwidth of an antenna vary as the gain is increased?
questions.answer: It decreases

questions.label: E9A07
questions.text: What is meant by antenna gain?
distractors: The ratio of the signal in the forward direction to that in the opposite direction
The ratio of the amount of power radiated by an antenna compared to the transmitter output power
The final amplifier gain minus the transmission line losses
questions.answer: The ratio of the radiated signal strength of an antenna in the direction of maximum radiation to that of a reference antenna

questions.label: E9A08
questions.text: What is meant by antenna bandwidth?
distractors: Antenna length divided by the number of elements
The angle between the half-power radiation points
The angle formed between two imaginary lines drawn through the element ends
questions.answer: The frequency range over which an antenna satisfies a performance requirement

questions.label: E9A09
questions.text: How is antenna efficiency calculated?
distractors: (effective radiated power / transmitter output) x 100 percent
questions.answer: (radiation resistance / total resistance) x 100 percent

questions.label: E9A10
questions.text: Which of the following choices is a way to improve the efficiency of a ground-mounted quarter-wave vertical antenna?
distractors: Isolate the coax shield from ground
Reduce the diameter of the radiating element
questions.answer: Install a good radial system

questions.label: E9A11
questions.text: Which of the following factors determines ground losses for a ground-mounted vertical antenna operating in the 3 MHz to 30 MHz range?
questions.answer: Soil conductivity

questions.label: E9A12
questions.text: How much gain does an antenna have compared to a 1/2-wavelength dipole when it has 6 dB gain over an isotropic antenna?

questions.label: E9A13
questions.text: How much gain does an antenna have compared to a 1/2-wavelength dipole when it has 12 dB gain over an isotropic antenna?

questions.label: E9A14
questions.text: What is meant by the radiation resistance of an antenna?
distractors: The combined losses of the antenna elements and feed line
The specific impedance of the antenna
The resistance in the atmosphere that an antenna must overcome to be able to radiate a signal
questions.answer: The value of a resistance that would dissipate the same amount of power as that radiated from an antenna

questions.label: E9A15
questions.text: What is the effective radiated power relative to a dipole of a repeater station with 150 watts transmitter power output, 2 dB feed line loss, 2.2 dB duplexer loss, and 7 dBd antenna gain?
questions.answer: 286 watts

questions.label: E9A16
questions.text: What is the effective radiated power relative to a dipole of a repeater station with 200 watts transmitter power output, 4 dB feed line loss, 3.2 dB duplexer loss, 0.8 dB circulator loss, and 10 dBd antenna gain?
questions.answer: 317 watts

questions.label: E9A17
questions.text: What is the effective radiated power of a repeater station with 200 watts transmitter power output, 2 dB feed line loss, 2.8 dB duplexer loss, 1.2 dB circulator loss, and 7 dBi antenna gain?
questions.answer: 252 watts

questions.label: E9A18
questions.text: What term describes station output, taking into account all gains and losses?
questions.answer: Effective radiated power

subTopics.label: E9B
subTopics.description: Antenna patterns: E and H plane patterns; gain as a function of pattern; antenna design

questions.label: E9B01
questions.text: In the antenna radiation pattern shown in Figure E9-1, what is the 3 dB beam-width?
questions.answer: 50 degrees

questions.label: E9B02
questions.text: In the antenna radiation pattern shown in Figure E9-1, what is the front-to-back ratio?
questions.answer: 18 dB

questions.label: E9B03
questions.text: In the antenna radiation pattern shown in Figure E9-1, what is the front-to-side ratio?
questions.answer: 14 dB

questions.label: E9B04
questions.text: What may occur when a directional antenna is operated at different frequencies within the band for which it was designed?
distractors: Feed point impedance may become negative
The E-field and H-field patterns may reverse
Element spacing limits could be exceeded
questions.answer: The gain may change depending on frequency

questions.label: E9B05
questions.text: What type of antenna pattern over real ground is shown in Figure E9-2?
questions.answer: Elevation

questions.label: E9B06
questions.text: What is the elevation angle of peak response in the antenna radiation pattern shown in Figure E9-2?
questions.answer: 7.5 degrees

questions.label: E9B07
questions.text: How does the total amount of radiation emitted by a directional gain antenna compare with the total amount of radiation emitted from an isotropic antenna, assuming each is driven by the same amount of power?
distractors: The total amount of radiation from the directional antenna is increased by the gain of the antenna
The total amount of radiation from the directional antenna is stronger by its front-to-back ratio
The radiation from the isotropic antenna is 2.15 dB stronger than that from the directional antenna
questions.answer: They are the same

questions.label: E9B08
questions.text: How can the approximate beam-width in a given plane of a directional antenna be determined?
distractors: Measure the ratio of the signal strengths of the radiated power lobes from the front and rear of the antenna
Draw two imaginary lines through the ends of the elements and measure the angle between the lines
Measure the ratio of the signal strengths of the radiated power lobes from the front and side of the antenna
questions.answer: Note the two points where the signal strength of the antenna is 3 dB less than maximum and compute the angular difference

questions.label: E9B09
questions.text: What type of computer program technique is commonly used for modeling antennas?
distractors: Calculus differentiation with respect to physical properties
questions.answer: Method of Moments

questions.label: E9B10
questions.text: What is the principle of a Method of Moments analysis?
distractors: A wire is modeled as a single sine-wave current generator
A wire is modeled as a series of points, each having a distinct location in space
A wire is modeled as a series of segments, each having a distinct value of voltage across it
questions.answer: A wire is modeled as a series of segments, each having a uniform value of current

questions.label: E9B11
questions.text: What is a disadvantage of decreasing the number of wire segments in an antenna model below the guideline of 10 segments per half-wavelength?
distractors: Ground conductivity will not be accurately modeled
The resulting design will favor radiation of harmonic energy
The antenna will become mechanically unstable
questions.answer: The computed feed point impedance may be incorrect

questions.label: E9B12
questions.text: What is the far field of an antenna?
distractors: The region of the ionosphere where radiated power is not refracted
The region where radiated power dissipates over a specified time period
The region where radiated field strengths are obstructed by objects of reflection
questions.answer: The region where the shape of the antenna pattern is independent of distance

questions.label: E9B13
questions.text: What does the abbreviation NEC stand for when applied to antenna modeling programs?
questions.answer: Numerical Electromagnetic Code

questions.label: E9B14
questions.text: What type of information can be obtained by submitting the details of a proposed new antenna to a modeling program?
distractors: Polar plots of the far field elevation and azimuth patterns
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E9B15
questions.text: What is the front-to-back ratio of the radiation pattern shown in Figure E9-2?
questions.answer: 28 dB

questions.label: E9B16
questions.text: How many elevation lobes appear in the forward direction of the antenna radiation pattern shown in Figure E9-2?

subTopics.label: E9C
subTopics.description: Wire and phased array antennas: rhombic antennas; effects of ground reflections; e-off angles; Practical wire antennas: Zepps, OCFD, loops

questions.label: E9C01
questions.text: What is the radiation pattern of two 1/4-wavelength vertical antennas spaced 1/2-wavelength apart and fed 180 degrees out of phase?
distractors: A figure-8 broadside to the axis of the array
questions.answer: A figure-8 oriented along the axis of the array

questions.label: E9C02
questions.text: What is the radiation pattern of two 1/4 wavelength vertical antennas spaced 1/4 wavelength apart and fed 90 degrees out of phase?
distractors: A figure-8 end-fire along the axis of the array
A figure-8 broadside to the axis of the array
questions.answer: Cardioid

questions.label: E9C03
questions.text: What is the radiation pattern of two 1/4 wavelength vertical antennas spaced 1/2 wavelength apart and fed in phase?
distractors: A Figure-8 end-fire along the axis of the array
questions.answer: A Figure-8 broadside to the axis of the array

questions.label: E9C04
questions.text: What happens to the radiation pattern of an unterminated long wire antenna as the wire length is increased?
distractors: The lobes become more perpendicular to the wire
questions.answer: The lobes align more in the direction of the wire

questions.label: E9C05
questions.text: What is an OCFD antenna?
distractors: A remotely tunable dipole antenna using orthogonally controlled frequency diversity
An eight band dipole antenna using octophase filters
A multiband dipole antenna using one-way circular polarization for frequency diversity
questions.answer: A dipole fed approximately 1/3 the way from one end with a 4:1 balun to provide multiband operation

questions.label: E9C06
questions.text: What is the effect of a terminating resistor on a rhombic antenna?
distractors: It reflects the standing waves on the antenna elements back to the transmitter
It changes the radiation pattern from horizontal to vertical polarization
questions.answer: It changes the radiation pattern from bidirectional to unidirectional

questions.label: E9C07
questions.text: What is the approximate feed point impedance at the center of a two-wire folded dipole antenna?
questions.answer: 300 ohms

questions.label: E9C08
questions.text: What is a folded dipole antenna?
distractors: A dipole configured to provide forward gain
questions.answer: A dipole consisting of one wavelength of wire forming a very thin loop

questions.label: E9C09
questions.text: What is a G5RV antenna?
distractors: A phased array antenna consisting of multiple loops
A wide band dipole using shorted coaxial cable for the radiating elements and fed with a 4:1 balun
questions.answer: A multi-band dipole antenna fed with coax and a balun through a selected length of open wire transmission line

questions.label: E9C10
questions.text: Which of the following describes a Zepp antenna?
distractors: A dipole constructed from zip cord
An omni-directional antenna commonly used for satellite communications
A vertical array capable of quickly changing the direction of maximum radiation by changing phasing lines
questions.answer: An end fed dipole antenna

questions.label: E9C11
questions.text: How is the far-field elevation pattern of a vertically polarized antenna affected by being mounted over seawater versus rocky ground?
distractors: Both the high-angle and low-angle radiation decrease
questions.answer: The low-angle radiation increases

questions.label: E9C12
questions.text: Which of the following describes an extended double Zepp antenna?
distractors: A wideband vertical antenna constructed from precisely tapered aluminum tubing
A portable antenna erected using two push support poles
An end fed folded dipole antenna
questions.answer: A center fed 1.25 wavelength antenna (two 5/8 wave elements in phase)

questions.label: E9C13
questions.text: What is the main effect of placing a vertical antenna over an imperfect ground?
distractors: It changes the impedance angle of the matching network
It reduces losses in the radiating portion of the antenna
questions.answer: It reduces low-angle radiation

questions.label: E9C14
questions.text: How does the performance of a horizontally polarized antenna mounted on the side of a hill compare with the same antenna mounted on flat ground?
distractors: The main lobe takeoff angle increases in the downhill direction
The horizontal beamwidth decreases in the downhill direction
The horizontal beamwidth increases in the uphill direction
questions.answer: The main lobe takeoff angle decreases in the downhill direction

questions.label: E9C15
questions.text: How does the radiation pattern of a horizontally polarized 3-element beam antenna vary with its height above ground?
distractors: The main lobe takeoff angle increases with increasing height
The horizontal beamwidth increases with height
The horizontal beamwidth decreases with height
questions.answer: The main lobe takeoff angle decreases with increasing height

subTopics.label: E9D
subTopics.description: Directional antennas: gain; Yagi Antennas; losses; SWR bandwidth; antenna efficiency; shortened and mobile antennas; RF Grounding

questions.label: E9D01
questions.text: How does the gain of an ideal parabolic dish antenna change when the operating frequency is doubled?
questions.answer: Gain increases by 6 dB

questions.label: E9D02
questions.text: How can linearly polarized Yagi antennas be used to produce circular polarization?
distractors: Stack two Yagis fed 90 degrees out of phase to form an array with the respective elements in parallel planes
Stack two Yagis fed in phase to form an array with the respective elements in parallel planes
Arrange two Yagis collinear to each other with the driven elements fed 180 degrees out of phase
questions.answer: Arrange two Yagis perpendicular to each other with the driven elements at the same point on the boom fed 90 degrees out of phase

questions.label: E9D03
questions.text: Where should a high Q loading coil be placed to minimize losses in a shortened vertical antenna?
distractors: As low as possible on the vertical radiator
As close to the transmitter as possible
questions.answer: Near the center of the vertical radiator

questions.label: E9D04
questions.text: Why should an HF mobile antenna loading coil have a high ratio of reactance to resistance?
questions.answer: To minimize losses

questions.label: E9D05
questions.text: What is a disadvantage of using a multiband trapped antenna?
distractors: It radiates the harmonics and fundamental equally well
It is too sharply directional at lower frequencies
questions.answer: It might radiate harmonics

questions.label: E9D06
questions.text: What happens to the bandwidth of an antenna as it is shortened through the use of loading coils?
questions.answer: It is decreased

questions.label: E9D07
questions.text: What is an advantage of using top loading in a shortened HF vertical antenna?
questions.answer: Improved radiation efficiency

questions.label: E9D08
questions.text: What happens as the Q of an antenna increases?
distractors: More common-mode current is present on the feed line
questions.answer: SWR bandwidth decreases

questions.label: E9D09
questions.text: What is the function of a loading coil used as part of an HF mobile antenna?
questions.answer: To cancel capacitive reactance

questions.label: E9D10
questions.text: What happens to feed point impedance at the base of a fixed length HF mobile antenna as the frequency of operation is lowered?
distractors: The radiation resistance decreases and the capacitive reactance decreases
The radiation resistance increases and the capacitive reactance decreases
The radiation resistance increases and the capacitive reactance increases
questions.answer: The radiation resistance decreases and the capacitive reactance increases

questions.label: E9D11
questions.text: Which of the following types of conductors would be best for minimizing losses in a station's RF ground system?
distractors: A resistive wire, such as spark plug wire
A cable with six or seven 18 gauge conductors in parallel
A single 12 gauge or 10 gauge stainless steel wire
questions.answer: A wide flat copper strap

questions.label: E9D12
questions.text: Which of the following would provide the best RF ground for your station?
distractors: A 50 ohm resistor connected to ground
An electrically short connection to a metal water pipe
An electrically short connection to 3 or 4 interconnected ground rods via a series RF choke
questions.answer: An electrically short connection to 3 or 4 interconnected ground rods driven into the Earth

questions.label: E9D13
questions.text: What usually occurs if a Yagi antenna is designed solely for maximum forward gain?
distractors: The frequency response is widened over the whole frequency band
questions.answer: The front-to-back ratio decreases

subTopics.label: E9E
subTopics.description: Matching: matching antennas to feed lines; phasing lines; power dividers

questions.label: E9E01
questions.text: What system matches a higher impedance transmission line to a lower impedance antenna by connecting the line to the driven element in two places spaced a fraction of a wavelength each side of element center?
questions.answer: The delta matching system

questions.label: E9E02
questions.text: What is the name of an antenna matching system that matches an unbalanced feed line to an antenna by feeding the driven element both at the center of the element and at a fraction of a wavelength to one side of center?
questions.answer: The gamma match

questions.label: E9E03
questions.text: What is the name of the matching system that uses a section of transmission line connected in parallel with the feed line at or near the feed point?
questions.answer: The stub match

questions.label: E9E04
questions.text: What is the purpose of the series capacitor in a gamma-type antenna matching network?
distractors: To provide DC isolation between the feed line and the antenna
To provide a rejection notch that prevents the radiation of harmonics
To transform the antenna impedance to a higher value
questions.answer: To cancel the inductive reactance of the matching network

questions.label: E9E05
questions.text: How must the driven element in a 3-element Yagi be tuned to use a hairpin matching system?
distractors: The driven element reactance must be inductive
The driven element resonance must be lower than the operating frequency
The driven element radiation resistance must be higher than the characteristic impedance of the transmission line
questions.answer: The driven element reactance must be capacitive

questions.label: E9E06
questions.text: What is the equivalent lumped-constant network for a hairpin matching system of a 3-element Yagi?
questions.answer: A shunt inductor

questions.label: E9E07
questions.text: What term best describes the interactions at the load end of a mismatched transmission line?
questions.answer: Reflection coefficient

questions.label: E9E08
questions.text: Which of the following measurements is characteristic of a mismatched transmission line?
questions.answer: An SWR greater than 1:1

questions.label: E9E09
questions.text: Which of these matching systems is an effective method of connecting a 50 ohm coaxial cable feed line to a grounded tower so it can be used as a vertical antenna?
distractors: All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Gamma match

questions.label: E9E10
questions.text: Which of these choices is an effective way to match an antenna with a 100 ohm feed point impedance to a 50 ohm coaxial cable feed line?
distractors: Connect a 1/4-wavelength open stub of 300 ohm twin-lead in parallel with the coaxial feed line where it connects to the antenna
Insert a 1/2 wavelength piece of 300 ohm twin-lead in series between the antenna terminals and the 50 ohm feed cable
Connect a 1/2 wavelength shorted stub of 75 ohm cable in parallel with the 50 ohm cable where it attaches to the antenna
questions.answer: Insert a 1/4-wavelength piece of 75 ohm coaxial cable transmission line in series between the antenna terminals and the 50 ohm feed cable

questions.label: E9E11
questions.text: What is an effective way of matching a feed line to a VHF or UHF antenna when the impedances of both the antenna and feed line are unknown?
distractors: Use a 50 ohm 1:1 balun between the antenna and feed line
Connect a series-resonant LC network across the antenna feed terminals
Connect a parallel-resonant LC network across the antenna feed terminals
questions.answer: Use the universal stub matching technique

questions.label: E9E12
questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a phasing line when used with an antenna having multiple driven elements?
distractors: It prevents reflected power from traveling back down the feed line and causing harmonic radiation from the transmitter
It allows single-band antennas to operate on other bands
It makes sure the antenna has a low-angle radiation pattern
questions.answer: It ensures that each driven element operates in concert with the others to create the desired antenna pattern

questions.label: E9E13
questions.text: What is a use for a Wilkinson divider?
distractors: It divides the operating frequency of a transmitter signal so it can be used on a lower frequency band
It is used to feed high-impedance antennas from a low-impedance source
It is used to feed low-impedance loads from a high-impedance source
questions.answer: It is used to divide power equally between two 50 ohm loads while maintaining 50 ohm input impedance

subTopics.label: E9F
subTopics.description: Transmission lines: characteristics of open and shorted feed lines; 1/8 wavelength; 1/4 wavelength; 1/2 wavelength; feed lines: coax versus open-wire; velocity factor; electrical length; coaxial cable dielectrics; velocity factor

questions.label: E9F01
questions.text: What is the velocity factor of a transmission line?
distractors: The ratio of the characteristic impedance of the line to the terminating impedance
The index of shielding for coaxial cable
The velocity of the wave in the transmission line multiplied by the velocity of light in a vacuum
questions.answer: The velocity of the wave in the transmission line divided by the velocity of light in a vacuum

questions.label: E9F02
questions.text: Which of the following determines the velocity factor of a transmission line?
questions.answer: Dielectric materials used in the line

questions.label: E9F03
questions.text: Why is the physical length of a coaxial cable transmission line shorter than its electrical length?
distractors: Skin effect is less pronounced in the coaxial cable
The characteristic impedance is higher in a parallel feed line
The surge impedance is higher in a parallel feed line
questions.answer: Electrical signals move more slowly in a coaxial cable than in air

questions.label: E9F04
questions.text: What is the typical velocity factor for a coaxial cable with solid polyethylene dielectric?

questions.label: E9F05
questions.text: What is the approximate physical length of a solid polyethylene dielectric coaxial transmission line that is electrically one-quarter wavelength long at 14.1 MHz?
questions.answer: 3.5 meters

questions.label: E9F06
questions.text: What is the approximate physical length of an air-insulated, parallel conductor transmission line that is electrically one-half wavelength long at 14.10 MHz?
questions.answer: 10 meters

questions.label: E9F07
questions.text: How does ladder line compare to small-diameter coaxial cable such as RG-58 at 50 MHz?
questions.answer: Lower loss

questions.label: E9F08
questions.text: What is the term for the ratio of the actual speed at which a signal travels through a transmission line to the speed of light in a vacuum?
questions.answer: Velocity factor

questions.label: E9F09
questions.text: What is the approximate physical length of a solid polyethylene dielectric coaxial transmission line that is electrically one-quarter wavelength long at 7.2 MHz?
questions.answer: 6.9 meters

questions.label: E9F10
questions.text: What impedance does a 1/8 wavelength transmission line present to a generator when the line is shorted at the far end?
distractors: The same as the characteristic impedance of the line
The same as the input impedance to the final generator stage
questions.answer: An inductive reactance

questions.label: E9F11
questions.text: What impedance does a 1/8 wavelength transmission line present to a generator when the line is open at the far end?
distractors: The same as the characteristic impedance of the line
The same as the input impedance of the final generator stage
questions.answer: A capacitive reactance

questions.label: E9F12
questions.text: What impedance does a 1/4 wavelength transmission line present to a generator when the line is open at the far end?
distractors: The same as the characteristic impedance of the line
The same as the input impedance to the generator
questions.answer: Very low impedance

questions.label: E9F13
questions.text: What impedance does a 1/4 wavelength transmission line present to a generator when the line is shorted at the far end?
distractors: The same as the characteristic impedance of the transmission line
The same as the generator output impedance
questions.answer: Very high impedance

questions.label: E9F14
questions.text: What impedance does a 1/2 wavelength transmission line present to a generator when the line is shorted at the far end?
distractors: The same as the characteristic impedance of the line
The same as the output impedance of the generator
questions.answer: Very low impedance

questions.label: E9F15
questions.text: What impedance does a 1/2 wavelength transmission line present to a generator when the line is open at the far end?
distractors: The same as the characteristic impedance of the line
The same as the output impedance of the generator
questions.answer: Very high impedance

questions.label: E9F16
questions.text: Which of the following is a significant difference between foam dielectric coaxial cable and solid dielectric cable, assuming all other parameters are the same?
distractors: Foam dielectric has lower safe operating voltage limits
Foam dielectric has lower loss per unit of length
Foam dielectric has higher velocity factor
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

subTopics.label: E9G
subTopics.description: The Smith chart

questions.label: E9G01
questions.text: Which of the following can be calculated using a Smith chart?
questions.answer: Impedance along transmission lines

questions.label: E9G02
questions.text: What type of coordinate system is used in a Smith chart?
questions.answer: Resistance circles and reactance arcs

questions.label: E9G03
questions.text: Which of the following is often determined using a Smith chart?
questions.answer: Impedance and SWR values in transmission lines

questions.label: E9G04
questions.text: What are the two families of circles and arcs that make up a Smith chart?
questions.answer: Resistance and reactance

questions.label: E9G05
questions.text: What type of chart is shown in Figure E9-3?
questions.answer: Smith chart

questions.label: E9G06
questions.text: On the Smith chart shown in Figure E9-3, what is the name for the large outer circle on which the reactance arcs terminate?
questions.answer: Reactance axis

questions.label: E9G07
questions.text: On the Smith chart shown in Figure E9-3, what is the only straight line shown?
questions.answer: The resistance axis

questions.label: E9G08
questions.text: What is the process of normalization with regard to a Smith chart?
distractors: Reassigning resistance values with regard to the reactance axis
Reassigning reactance values with regard to the resistance axis
Reassigning prime center with regard to the reactance axis
questions.answer: Reassigning impedance values with regard to the prime center

questions.label: E9G09
questions.text: What third family of circles is often added to a Smith chart during the process of solving problems?
questions.answer: Standing wave ratio circles

questions.label: E9G10
questions.text: What do the arcs on a Smith chart represent?
questions.answer: Points with constant reactance

questions.label: E9G11
questions.text: How are the wavelength scales on a Smith chart calibrated?
distractors: In fractions of transmission line electrical frequency
In fractions of antenna electrical wavelength
In fractions of antenna electrical frequency
questions.answer: In fractions of transmission line electrical wavelength

subTopics.label: E9H
subTopics.description: Receiving Antennas: radio direction finding antennas; Beverage Antennas; specialized receiving antennas; longwire receiving antennas

questions.label: E9H01
questions.text: When constructing a Beverage antenna, which of the following factors should be included in the design to achieve good performance at the desired frequency?
distractors: Its overall length must not exceed 1/4 wavelength
It must be mounted more than 1 wavelength above ground
It should be configured as a four-sided loop
questions.answer: It should be one or more wavelengths long

questions.label: E9H02
questions.text: Which is generally true for low band (160 meter and 80 meter) receiving antennas?
distractors: They must be erected at least 1/2 wavelength above the ground to attain good directivity
Low loss coax transmission line is essential for good performance
All of these choices are correct
questions.answer: Atmospheric noise is so high that gain over a dipole is not important

questions.label: E9H04
questions.text: What is an advantage of using a shielded loop antenna for direction finding?
distractors: It automatically cancels ignition noise in mobile installations
It eliminates tracking errors caused by strong out-of-band signals
It allows stations to communicate without giving away their position
questions.answer: It is electro statically balanced against ground, giving better nulls

questions.label: E9H05
questions.text: What is the main drawback of a wire-loop antenna for direction finding?
distractors: It receives equally well in all directions
It is practical for use only on VHF bands
questions.answer: It has a bidirectional pattern

questions.label: E9H06
questions.text: What is the triangulation method of direction finding?
distractors: The geometric angles of sky waves from the source are used to determine its position
A fixed receiving station plots three headings to the signal source
A fixed receiving station uses three different antennas to plot the location of the signal source
questions.answer: Antenna headings from several different receiving locations are used to locate the signal source

questions.label: E9H07
questions.text: Why is it advisable to use an RF attenuator on a receiver being used for direction finding?
distractors: It narrows the bandwidth of the received signal to improve signal to noise ratio
It compensates for the effects of an isotropic antenna, thereby improving directivity
It reduces loss of received signals caused by antenna pattern nulls, thereby increasing sensitivity
questions.answer: It prevents receiver overload which could make it difficult to determine peaks or nulls

questions.label: E9H08
questions.text: What is the function of a sense antenna?
distractors: It increases the sensitivity of a DF antenna array
It allows DF antennas to receive signals at different vertical angles
It provides diversity reception that cancels multipath signals
questions.answer: It modifies the pattern of a DF antenna array to provide a null in one direction

questions.label: E9H09
questions.text: Which of the following describes the construction of a receiving loop antenna?
distractors: A small coil of wire tightly wound around a toroidal ferrite core
A vertical antenna coupled to a feed line through an inductive loop of wire
questions.answer: One or more turns of wire wound in the shape of a large open coil

questions.label: E9H10
questions.text: How can the output voltage of a multiple turn receiving loop antenna be increased?
distractors: By reducing the permeability of the loop shield
By increasing the number of wire turns in the loop and reducing the area of the loop structure
By winding adjacent turns in opposing directions
questions.answer: By increasing either the number of wire turns in the loop or the area of the loop structure or both

questions.label: E9H11
questions.text: What characteristic of a cardioid pattern antenna is useful for direction finding?
questions.answer: A very sharp single null

subTopics.label: E0A
subTopics.description: Safety: amateur radio safety practices; RF radiation hazards; hazardous materials; grounding

questions.label: E0A01
questions.text: What is the primary function of an external earth connection or ground rod?
distractors: Reduce RF current flow between pieces of equipment
Reduce RFI to telephones and home entertainment systems
questions.answer: Lightning protection

questions.label: E0A02
questions.text: When evaluating RF exposure levels from your station at a neighbor’s home, what must you do?
distractors: Make sure signals from your station are less than the controlled MPE limits
You need only evaluate exposure levels on your own property
Advise your neighbors of the results of your tests
questions.answer: Make sure signals from your station are less than the uncontrolled MPE limits

questions.label: E0A03
questions.text: Which of the following would be a practical way to estimate whether the RF fields produced by an amateur radio station are within permissible MPE limits?
distractors: Use a hand calculator plus Smith-chart equations to calculate the fields
All of the choices are correct
questions.answer: Use an antenna modeling program to calculate field strength at accessible locations

questions.label: E0A04
questions.text: When evaluating a site with multiple transmitters operating at the same time, the operators and licensees of which transmitters are responsible for mitigating over-exposure situations?
distractors: Each transmitter operating with a duty-cycle greater than 50 percent
questions.answer: Each transmitter that produces 5 percent or more of its MPE limit at accessible locations

questions.label: E0A05
questions.text: What is one of the potential hazards of using microwaves in the amateur radio bands?
distractors: Microwaves often travel long distances by ionospheric reflection
The extremely high frequency energy can damage the joints of antenna structures
questions.answer: The high gain antennas commonly used can result in high exposure levels

questions.label: E0A06
questions.text: Why are there separate electric (E) and magnetic (H) field MPE limits?
distractors: The body reacts to electromagnetic radiation from both the E and H fields
Ground reflections and scattering make the field impedance vary with location
E field and H field radiation intensity peaks can occur at different locations
questions.answer: All of these choices are correct

questions.label: E0A07
questions.text: How may dangerous levels of carbon monoxide from an emergency generator be detected?
distractors: Any ordinary smoke detector can be used
By the yellowish appearance of the gas
questions.answer: Only with a carbon monoxide detector

questions.label: E0A08
questions.text: What does SAR measure?
distractors: Synthetic Aperture Ratio of the human body
The rate of RF energy reflected from stationary terrain
questions.answer: The rate at which RF energy is absorbed by the body

questions.label: E0A09
questions.text: Which insulating material commonly used as a thermal conductor for some types of electronic devices is extremely toxic if broken or crushed and the particles are accidentally inhaled?
questions.answer: Beryllium Oxide

questions.label: E0A10
questions.text: What toxic material may be present in some electronic components such as high voltage capacitors and transformers?
questions.answer: Polychlorinated Biphenyls

questions.label: E0A11
questions.text: Which of the following injuries can result from using high-power UHF or microwave transmitters?
distractors: Hearing loss caused by high voltage corona discharge
Blood clotting from the intense magnetic field
Ingestion of ozone gas from the cooling system
questions.answer: Localized heating of the body from RF exposure in excess of the MPE limits
